message.content: Case Overview: Case Name: Verein für Konsumenteninformation v. Amazon EU Sàrl Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), Third Chamber Date: 28 July 2016 Reference: C-191/15 Key Legal Issues: - Application of Rome I and Rome II Regulations for determining law in consumer protection actions. - Unfair terms under Directive 93/13/EEC. - Applicability of data protection laws under Directive 95/46/EC. Core Facts: - Amazon EU Sàrl, a Luxembourg established company, used general terms and conditions (GTC) in its contracts with Austrian consumers via electronic commerce. - The GTC included a choice-of-law clause selecting Luxembourg law. - Verein für Konsumenteninformation (VKI) sued for an injunction, alleging the GTC were unfair and violated consumer protection laws. Judgment: Applicable Law for Actions: The law applicable to an action for an injunction against unfair terms is determined by Rome II Regulation Art. 6(1). The applicable law for term assessment is determined by Rome I Regulation. - Unfair Terms: The court held that a choice-of-law term is unfair under Directive 93/13 if it misleads the consumer into believing only the seller's law applies without clarifying the protection under the consumer's local mandatory laws. - Data Protection Law: Processing of personal data by an e-commerce entity is subject to the data protection law of the Member State where the entity directs its activities if data processing occurs in the context of an establishment’s activities in that Member State, per Directive 95/46/EC. Applicable Law: - Rome I Regulation: Determines the law applicable to specific contract terms. - Rome II Regulation: Determines the law applicable to non-contractual obligations. - Directive 93/13: Governs assessment of unfair terms in consumer contracts. - Directive 95/46/EC: Governs data protection laws applicable to cross-border e-commerce activities. Reasoning: - The laws of the consumer’s residence apply to terms impacting consumer protection to ensure higher protection standards. - Terms in GTC must be clear and not cause significant imbalance; consumers should be informed of their protection under applicable mandatory laws. Impact: - Clarifies the application of consumer protection laws in cross-border e-commerce disputes regarding contractual terms. - Ensures consumer rights in their country of residence are upheld, even when contracting with entities in other Member States. - Establishes the broad scope of lawful data processing regulations for e-commerce within the EU.

Case Overview: Case Name: Ryneš v. Úřad pro ochranu osobních údajů Court: Fourth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 11 December 2014 Reference: C-212/13 Key Legal Issues: - Definition of "processing of personal data" (Article 2(b) Directive 95/46/EC) - Interpretation of "purely personal or household activity" (Article 3(2) Directive 95/46/EC) - Applicability of Directive 95/46/EC to video surveillance covering public spaces Core Facts: - Mr. Ryneš installed a fixed camera system on his family home, recording both private and public spaces, to protect against repeated attacks on his property. - The recorded video assisted in identifying suspects involved in a specific attack. - The Czech Data Protection Office determined Mr. Ryneš violated data protection laws by not obtaining consent and failing to notify individuals or authorities about the data processing. Judgment: - The court ruled that video surveillance extending to public spaces does not qualify as a "purely personal or household activity" under Article 3(2) Directive 95/46/EC. - Such activities must comply with Directive 95/46/EC, despite being conducted by natural persons for personal protection. Applicable Law: - Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(a), 2(b), 3(1), 3(2), 7(f), 11, 13 Reasoning: - Personal data includes video images if individuals can be identified. - The processing of personal data must be strictly for personal or household settings to qualify for exemption. - Monitoring public spaces does not meet the "purely personal or household activity" criteria and thus falls within the Directive's scope. Impact: - Clarifies that video surveillance capturing public areas must adhere to data protection regulations, even if intended for personal security. - Strengthens the interpretative framework ensuring the high level of protection for personal data under EU law. - Provides guidance for evaluating similar cases involving personal data processing and public surveillance.

Case Overview: Case Name: GC and Others v. CNIL Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 24 September 2019 Reference: C-136/17 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 8(1) and (5) of Directive 95/46/EC regarding the processing of special categories of personal data by search engine operators. Requirements for de-referencing requests related to such special data under Article 8(2). Balancing the right to privacy/data protection with freedom of information under Articles 7, 8, and 11 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Core Facts: GC, AF, BH, and ED requested Google to de-reference links to web pages containing sensitive personal data. Google refused these requests, leading to complaints filed with the French Data Protection Authority (CNIL), which subsequently rejected to take action. Applicants sought judicial review by the Conseil d’État (Council of State, France), which referred several questions to the CJEU. Judgment: Search Engine Responsibilities: Search engine operators must comply with prohibitions and restrictions in Article 8(1) and (5) of Directive 95/46, subject to exceptions. They are required to verify de-referencing requests and ensure compliance with data protection requirements. Exceptions: Search engines may refuse de-referencing if the data falls within exceptions provided in Article 8(2)(e), such as if the data was manifestly made public by the data subject. Fundamental Rights Balance: In cases involving sensitive data, search engines must balance privacy rights against freedom of information. Each de-referencing request must be assessed in context to determine if including the data link is necessary for public information interests. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC Articles: 8(1), 8(2), 8(5), 12(b), 14(a) Regulation (EU) 2016/679 Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Articles 7, 8, 11 Reasoning: Processing of sensitive data by search engines can be subject to the same restrictions as other data controllers. Even initially lawful data processing may become unlawful if data becomes inadequate, irrelevant, or excessive over time. The nature of the offense, public interest, and the current relevance of legal proceedings must be considered. Impact: Clarifies the scope and responsibility of search engines under GDPR with respect to handling sensitive personal data. Provides framework for balancing individual privacy against public information rights in the context of data searches.

Case Overview: - Case Name: College van burgemeester en wethouders van Rotterdam v. M.E.E. Rijkeboer - Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union - Date: 7 May 2009 - Reference: C-553/07 Key Legal Issues: - Right of access to personal data and information on recipients under Directive 95/46/EC. - Time-limit on the exercise of the right to access data. Core Facts: - Mr. Rijkeboer requested information on the recipients of his personal data for two years preceding his request. - The College van burgemeester en wethouders van Rotterdam only provided data for the one year preceding the request, as per Dutch law. Judgment: - Right of Access to Past Data: Article 12(a) of Directive 95/46/EC requires Member States to ensure access to information on recipients of personal data not only in the present but also in the past. - Time-Limit Imposed: National laws must fix a time-limit for storing this information that balances the data subject's rights and the burden on the data controller. - Excessive Burden: Limiting storage of recipient data to one year is not inherently a fair balance unless longer storage would place an excessive burden on the controller. Applicable Law: - Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 1, 2, 6(1)(e), 10, 11, 12(a), 13, 14, 17, 22, 23. Reasoning: - The right to access past data ensures the data subject can exercise rights to rectification, erasure, and legal remedies. - Member States must set a fair time-limit considering the burden on controllers and the need to protect privacy. Impact: - Establishes that Member States must provide access to historical data on recipients of personal information. - Requires balancing the interests of data subjects and the operational burdens on data controllers. - National courts must assess whether longer storage imposes an excessive burden.

Case Overview: Case Name: StWL Städtische Werke Lauf a.d. Pegnitz GmbH v. eprimo GmbH Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 25 November 2021 Reference: C-102/20 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of "electronic mail" (Article 2(h) Directive 2002/58) Definition and use of electronic mail for direct marketing purposes (Article 13(1) Directive 2002/58) Persistent and unwanted solicitations (Annex I, Point 26, Directive 2005/29) Core Facts: eprimo GmbH, requested advertisements to be displayed in the inboxes of T-Online email users. These ads appeared similar to regular emails, disrupting the inboxes and requiring user interaction to remove them. StWL claimed these practices violated rules against unsolicited communications and unfair commercial practices. Judgment: Use of Electronic Mail: Ads displayed in email inboxes in the form of emails are considered as electronic mail used for direct marketing under Article 13(1) of Directive 2002/58. Requirement for Prior Consent: Such display requires that the user was clearly and specifically informed and had consented to these ads appearing in their inboxes. Persistent and Unwanted Solicitations: The practice of displaying ads frequently and without prior consent fits the definition of “persistent and unwanted solicitations” under Annex I, Point 26 to Directive 2005/29. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC (E-Privacy Directive): Articles 2(h), 13(1) Directive 2005/29/EC (Unfair Commercial Practices Directive): Annex I, Point 26 Reasoning: The advertising was deemed intrusive as it mimicked real emails, requiring user interaction to clear, thereby falling under unsolicited communications and necessitating prior consent. Ads in email inboxes are similar to spam, imposing a burden on users and invading privacy, thus, constituting unfair commercial practices. Impact: Clarifies the scope of electronic mail in the context of direct marketing and associated consent requirements. Establishes that frequent and unsolicited ad placements in email must be informed and consented to by users. Sets a precedent for handling unsolicited communications and persistent unwanted solicitations.

Case Overview: Case Name: Commissioner of the Garda Síochána and Others Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), Grand Chamber Date: 5 April 2022 Reference: C-140/20 Key Legal Issues: Legality of General and Indiscriminate Retention of Traffic and Location Data Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC in Light of Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52(1) of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights Procedural Requirements for Access to Retained Data Core Facts: G.D. challenged the validity of Ireland's Communications (Retention of Data) Act 2011, which required general retention of traffic and location data. Traffic and location data were used as evidence in G.D.’s criminal trial for murder. G.D. argued that the 2011 Act infringed EU law based on CJEU precedents. Judgment: General and Indiscriminate Retention: The Court ruled that preventive, general, and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data for combating serious crime is not permitted under Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC, read in light of the Charter. Targeted and Specific Retention: Allowed under strict conditions (e.g., targeted retention based on objective criteria, general retention of IP addresses, and data relating to civil identity, expedited retention by order of competent authority subject to review). Procedural Requirements: Centralized processing of access requests by police officers within the same investigation authority violates the requirement for independent prior review. Temporal Effects: National courts cannot limit the temporal effects of a declaration of invalidity regarding the national legislation that conflicts with EU law. Admissibility of evidence derived from such retention is subject to national law, adhering to principles of equivalence and effectiveness. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC, as amended by Directive 2009/136/EC Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52(1) of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights Reasoning: The Court emphasized the primacy of EU law and the necessity of strict proportionality and specificity in data retention measures. Only specific, targeted retention aligned with fundamental rights safeguards is permissible, not general and indiscriminate retention. Impact: Clarifies limits on data retention laws for EU Member States. Emphasizes the need for independent prior review before accessing retained data. Reinforces the balance between combating serious crime and protecting fundamental rights under the EU Charter.

Case Overview: Case Name: Koalitsia Demokratichna Bulgaria - Obedinenie Court: Eighth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 20 October 2022 Reference: C-306/21 Key Legal Issues: Material Scope of GDPR: Whether the GDPR applies to the processing of personal data during national elections (Article 2(2)(a)) Lawfulness of Processing: Legitimacy of processing personal data during elections (Article 6(1)(e)) Supervisory Authorities: Powers to limit or prohibit video recording during vote count (Article 58) Core Facts: Bulgarian political parties challenged guidelines by Bulgarian authorities requiring limits/prohibition on video recordings during elections. The guidelines were intended to ensure transparency, objectivity, and legality of the electoral process while protecting personal data. Judgment: Applicability of GDPR: The GDPR applies to personal data processing in the context of national elections. Supervisory Measures: National authorities can impose general measures limiting or prohibiting video recording during the vote count in elections, provided such measures are proportionate and ensure data protection. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 2(2)(a), 6(1)(e), 58 Recitals of GDPR: 4, 16, 129 Reasoning: Material Scope: Activities related to elections do not fall under the exception of activities outside Union law. Lawfulness of Processing: Measures must align with public interest tasks and be based on legal frameworks. Proportionality: Measures taken by supervisory authorities should minimally interfere with the rights of data protection, ensuring transparency and fairness. Impact: Clarifies the scope of GDPR applicability to national electoral processes. Affirms the supervisory authority's capacity to regulate personal data processing to ensure compliance with GDPR during elections. Sets precedent for balancing data protection with the need for transparency in electoral processes.

Case Overview: Case Name: Ligue des droits humains ASBL and BA v. Organe de contrôle de l’information policière Court: Fifth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 16 November 2023 Reference: C-333/22 Key Legal Issues: Right to effective judicial remedy (Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU) Protection of personal data (Article 8(3) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU) Interpretation and validity of Article 17 of Directive (EU) 2016/680 Core Facts: BA sought security clearance from the National Security Authority, which was denied based on participation in demonstrations. BA requested the Organe de contrôle de l’information policière (OCIP) to verify and provide access to his personal data processed by Belgian police, which was denied except to inform that verifications had taken place. BA and Ligue des droits humains filed for judicial review, questioning the legality of OCIP’s limited disclosure. Judgment: Effective Judicial Remedy: The data subject must have access to an effective judicial remedy against the supervisory authority's decision to close the verification process under Article 17 of Directive 2016/680. Validity of Article 17(3): Article 17(3) of Directive 2016/680 is valid under EU law, provided Member States ensure that the right to effective judicial protection is not substantively hindered and that procedural safeguards are in place. Applicable Law: Directive (EU) 2016/680: Articles 1, 13-17, 42, 46-47, 53-54 Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Article 8(3), Article 47 TFEU: Article 267 (preliminary ruling procedure) Reasoning: Supervisory Authorities' Decisions: OCIP’s actions and communications constitute legally binding decisions impacting the data subject’s legal position, thus warranting judicial review. Minimum Information Provision: Article 17(3) aligns with public interest restrictions and allows for judicial review to ensure effective remedies and balanced rights protection. Impact: Establishes the necessity for judicial remedies against supervisory authorities. Confirms the validity and application scope of Article 17(3) of Directive 2016/680. Reinforces procedural and substantive safeguards ensuring effective judicial protection for data subjects.

Case Overview: Case Name: UF & AB v. Land Hessen & SCHUFA Holding AG Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 7 December 2023 Reference: C-26/22 & C-64/22 Key Legal Issues: Right to an effective judicial remedy against a supervisory authority (Article 78(1) GDPR) Principle of lawfulness, fairness, and transparency in data processing (Article 5(1)(a) GDPR) Lawfulness of processing - Legitimate interest (Article 6(1)(f) GDPR) Right to erasure ("right to be forgotten") (Article 17(1) GDPR) Codes of conduct (Article 40 GDPR) Core Facts: SCHUFA Holding AG, a private credit information agency, stored information about the discharge of remaining debts in its own database beyond the six-month period specified for public records. UF and AB requested the deletion of their personal data, but SCHUFA refused, citing its compliance with a longer retention period pursuant to an approved code of conduct. UF and AB filed complaints with the Hessian Data Protection Authority (HBDI), which ruled that SCHUFA's data processing was lawful. UF and AB sought judicial review of HBDI's decision. Judgment: Full Judicial Review: The Court held that decisions by supervisory authorities about complaints must be subject to full judicial review, ensuring comprehensive assessment of the facts and law. Retention of Data by Credit Information Agencies: The retention of information in private databases beyond the period allowed for public databases conflicts with GDPR principles. Processing personal data for a period longer than required changes the balance of legitimate interests versus data subject rights. Right to Erasure: If data are unlawfully processed or if the data subject objects to the processing and there are no overriding legitimate grounds, the data must be erased promptly. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 5(1)(a), 6(1)(f), 17(1)(c), 17(1)(d), 40, 78(1) Reasoning: Emphasized the need for a full judicial review to provide effective legal remedies. Emphasized legitimate interest must be balanced against data subject rights, taking into account the strict necessity and reasonable expectations. Clarified that public and private data retention practices must be consistent to avoid unjustified intrusions on privacy. Impact: Strengthens judicial oversight over supervisory authorities' decisions under the GDPR. Reinforces data subjects' rights to transparency and lawful processing. Limits how long private entities can retain personal data, aligning it with public data retention periods to protect individual privacy.

Case Overview: - Case Name: Maximillian Schrems v. Data Protection Commissioner - Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union - Date: 6 October 2015 - Reference: C-362/14 (Schrems I) Key Legal Issues: - Adequacy of protection for personal data transferred to third countries under Directive 95/46/EC. - Interpretation of Articles 7, 8, and 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. - Validity of the Commission Decision 2000/520 (Safe Harbour). Core Facts: - Maximillian Schrems challenged the transfer of his personal data to the US by Facebook Ireland, citing inadequate protection against US intelligence activities. - The Data Protection Commissioner refused to investigate Schrems' complaint, relying on Commission Decision 2000/520, which deemed US data protection adequate. - High Court (Ireland) referred questions on the supervisory authority's powers and the decision's validity to the CJEU. Judgment: - National Supervisory Authority's Role: - National supervisory authorities retain the power to examine claims about data transfers to third countries even if a Commission decision exists affirming data protection adequacy. - Invalidity of Commission Decision 2000/520: - The Decision failed to ensure that the US provided an adequate level of protection for personal data. - National security and public interest exemptions in the Safe Harbour Principles allow excessive interference, lacking essential safeguards and legal protections for EU citizens. - Therefore, Decision 2000/520 was ruled invalid. Applicable Law: - Directive 95/46/EC (Articles 25 and 28) - Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (Articles 7, 8, and 47) Reasoning: - Adequate protection requires a level essentially equivalent to that in the EU. - Overarching national security exemptions and lack of effective legal protection in the US undermine fundamental rights. - National supervisory authorities must ensure EU law compliance and address fundamental rights violations. Impact: - Invalidates the Safe Harbour framework, impacting future data transfers to the US. - Reinforces supervisory authorities' roles in protecting data under GDPR and the Charter. - Necessitates robust measures in international data transfer adequacy decisions.

Case Overview: Case Name: Peter Puškár v. Finančné riaditeľstvo Slovenskej republiky and Kriminálny úrad finančnej správy Court: Court of Justice of the European Union, Second Chamber Date: 27 September 2017 Reference: C-73/16 Key Legal Issues: Right to an effective remedy and fair trial under Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Lawfulness, purpose limitation, and data minimization principles under Directive 95/46/EC (Data Protection Directive). Core Facts: Mr. Puškár challenged the inclusion of his name on a list of alleged "front-men" for tax purposes, managed by the Slovak tax authorities. The Slovak Supreme Court required exhaustion of administrative remedies before judicial review. Mr. Puškár's case involved data on the list being collected and used without consent, purportedly for tax collection and anti-fraud purposes. Judgment: Administrative Remedies: Article 47 does not preclude requiring exhaustion of administrative remedies if such requirements do not disproportionally affect the right to an effective remedy. Evidence Submission: National legislation can reject evidence (like Mr. Puškár’s list) obtained without required consent only if it respects the essential content of the right to an effective remedy. Processing of Personal Data: Permissible without consent under Article 7(e) of Directive 95/46/EC for public interest tasks (such as tax collection and anti-fraud), given the tasks are lawful, necessary, and adequately protected. Applicable Law: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 7, 8, and 47 Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 1, 7, 12, 13 TEU: Article 4(3) TFEU: Article 267 Reasoning: Ensuring an effective judicial remedy is balanced against administrative efficiency and proportionality. Legal basis for data processing includes safeguarding economic and financial state interests. Confirms member states' capability to impose administrative exhaustion preconditions and still comply with the Charter. Impact: Clarifies the interaction between administrative remedies and judicial review under EU law while reinforcing the conditions under which data processing by public authorities is permissible without consent.

Case Overview: Case Name: Asociación Nacional de Establecimientos Financieros de Crédito (ASNEF) v. Administración del Estado Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Third Chamber) Date: 24 November 2011 Reference: C-468/10 and C-469/10 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 7(f) of Directive 95/46/EC (Data Protection Directive) Direct effect of Article 7(f) of Directive 95/46/EC Core Facts: Spanish law requires that for personal data to be processed without the data subject’s consent, the data must come from public sources. ASNEF and FECEMD challenge the additional condition imposed by Spanish law as being contrary to Directive 95/46/EC. Judgment: Preclusion of Additional National Conditions: Article 7(f) precludes national rules that impose additional requirements, such as the data appearing in public sources, for processing personal data without consent. Direct Effect: Article 7(f) has a direct effect and can be relied upon by individuals against the State. Applicable Law: Article 7(f), 5, 13 of Directive 95/46/EC Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union Reasoning: The directive aims to harmonize data protection laws across the EU, ensuring a high and equivalent level of protection without additional national restrictions. Article 7(f) contains exhaustive conditions, and allowing states to add extra conditions undermines the directive’s objective. The provision is sufficiently precise and unconditional, meeting the criteria for direct effect. Impact: Clarifies limits on Member States' ability to impose additional conditions on data processing. Reinforces the harmonization objective of the Data Protection Directive. Affirms the direct effect of key provisions of the Directive, strengthening individual rights under EU law.

Case Overview: - Case Name: Deutsche Wohnen SE v. Staatsanwaltschaft Berlin - Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union - Date: 5 December 2023 - Reference: C-807/21 Key Legal Issues: - Interpretation of GDPR's Article 83(4) to (6) regarding the imposition of administrative fines on legal persons. - Determination of whether an infringement must be attributed to an identified natural person. - Requirement of intentional or negligent conduct for fines under GDPR. Core Facts: - Deutsche Wohnen SE (DW) challenged an administrative fine imposed by the Berlin Data Protection Authority for GDPR violations. - The fine related to failures in erasing tenants' personal data which were no longer necessary. - The German court questioned whether national law was in line with GDPR requirements for attributing liability to legal persons. Judgment: - Legal Person Liability: The GDPR allows administrative fines to be imposed directly on legal persons (controllers) without requiring the infringement to be first attributed to an identified natural person. - Intentional or Negligent Conduct: An administrative fine under GDPR can only be imposed if the infringement is committed intentionally or negligently by the controller. - Scope of Responsibility: Legal persons are liable for infringements committed by anyone acting on their behalf, not limited to representatives or directors. Applicable Law: - GDPR Articles: 4(7), 58(2), 83(1) to (6) - Specific Fines and Conduct: Article 6, Article 25(1), Article 5(1)(a), (c), and (e) Reasoning: - The GDPR aims to provide a high level of uniform data protection across the EU by enforcing direct responsibility on legal persons for data processing infringements. - The requirement for intentional or negligent conduct ensures that fines are effective, proportionate, and dissuasive without imposing strict liability. Impact: - Emphasizes that administrative fines under GDPR can be applied directly to legal entities without needing to identify a natural person responsible. - Ensures parity in GDPR's application across Member States, reinforcing the data protection framework's consistency. - Clarifies that wrongdoing (intentional or negligent actions) is a necessary condition for imposing administrative fines on controllers under GDPR.

Case Overview: Case Name: LSG-Gesellschaft zur Wahrnehmung von Leistungsschutzrechten GmbH v. Tele2 Telecommunication GmbH Court: Eighth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 19 February 2009 Reference: C-557/07 Key Legal Issues: Disclosure of personal data to private parties for civil copyright infringement proceedings. Definition of "intermediaries" under Directive 2001/29/EC. Balancing privacy rights with the enforcement of intellectual property rights. Core Facts: LSG sought names and addresses of individuals from Tele2, an Internet access provider, to pursue civil copyright infringement claims. Tele2, providing only internet access without additional services, refused to disclose the requested information. Judgment: Disclosure of Personal Data: Article 8(3) of Directive 2004/48/EC, read with Directive 2002/58/EC, does not prevent Member States from mandating the disclosure of personal data to private parties for civil proceedings. National transposition must balance fundamental rights, ensuring consistency with EU directives and general principles of EU law, such as proportionality. Definition of Intermediaries: Access providers, even if only providing internet access without additional control, qualify as "intermediaries" under Article 8(3) of Directive 2001/29/EC. Such intermediaries can be obligated to assist in identifying individuals involved in copyright infringements. Applicable Law: Directives: 2000/31/EC, 2001/29/EC, 2002/58/EC, 2004/48/EC GDPR: Article 13(1) of Directive 95/46/EC Reasoning: Personal Data Disclosure: Member States can impose disclosure obligations but must ensure fair balance between privacy and intellectual property rights, adhering to principles like proportionality. Intermediary Definition: Even basic internet access provision involves the intermediary in potential copyright infringements, justifying their inclusion under "intermediaries". Impact: Clarifies the responsibilities of internet access providers as intermediaries under EU copyright law. Emphasizes the need for balanced national laws aligning privacy rights with intellectual property enforcement. Ensures that internet access providers may be obligated to provide information aiding in the enforcement of intellectual property rights in a civil context.

Case Overview: Case Name: Inspektor v Inspektorata kam Visshia sadeben savet Court: Fifth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 8 December 2022 Reference: C-180/21 Key Legal Issues: Application of GDPR and LED to processing of personal data initially collected for criminal investigations and subsequently used for different purposes. Definition and scope of "legitimate interest" and "public interest" in data processing. Conditions for subsequent processing of data under Directive (EU) 2016/680 (LED). Core Facts: VS's personal data were collected as a victim in a criminal investigation but later used to prosecute him and defend against his claim for damages due to delayed proceedings. Dispute over whether the use of data related to VS in a civil damages case against the State violates data protection laws. Judgment: Different Processing Purpose: The Court held that using personal data initially collected for one purpose (e.g., investigation) for another purpose (e.g., prosecution or defense) is permissible if it meets conditions under Article 4(2) of LED. Application of GDPR: The GDPR applies to the processing of personal data by the public prosecutor for defending a civil action, even if the data were initially collected for criminal investigation. Lawfulness of Processing: The use of the data for defending against the civil action can be deemed lawful under Article 6(1)(e) of GDPR if it is necessary for tasks carried out in the public interest. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 2(1), 2(2), 4(1), 4(2), 6(1)(e), 9(1), 9(2) LED: Articles 1(1), 3(8), 4(2), and 6. Reasoning: Different Purposes: The Court distinguished between various categories of data processing purposes under Article 1(1) of LED and emphasized the need for compliance with specific conditions for lawful subsequent processing. GDPR Application: Clarified the GDPR's broad scope and the limited nature of exceptions under Article 2(2)(d). Public Authority's Legitimate Interest: Established that public authorities can process data for defending against legal claims if such processing is covered by national law and complies with GDPR requirements, particularly if it serves public interest tasks. Impact: Provides clarity on the permissible scope of subsequent data processing under the LED and GDPR. Establishes limits and conditions for using personal data collected in criminal investigations for different legal purposes. Reinforces the application of GDPR to certain activities of public authorities beyond criminal investigations.

Case Overview: Case Name: Ministerio Fiscal Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 2 October 2018 Reference: C-207/16 Key Legal Issues: Access of national authorities to personal data retained by electronic communications providers. Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC (E-privacy Directive) in light of Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (right to private life and protection of personal data). Core Facts: A mobile phone was stolen, and the police sought judicial authorization to access personal data retained by electronic communication providers to identify the owners of SIM cards activated with the stolen phone. The data requested included telephone numbers, surnames, forenames, and addresses but not the actual communications or location data. Judgment: Interference with Fundamental Rights: The access of public authorities to data to identify SIM card owners is considered an interference with fundamental rights under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter. Such interference is not deemed "serious" and thus does not require restriction to fighting serious crimes. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC (E-privacy Directive) Articles: 1, 3, 5, 6, 15(1) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Articles 7 (private life) and 8 (protection of personal data). Reasoning: The Court distinguished between serious and non-serious interferences with fundamental rights. Access to data that only identifies SIM card owners without providing insight into the content of communications or the location does not allow drawing precise conclusions about individuals’ private lives. Impact: This judgment clarifies the threshold for what constitutes "serious" interference with fundamental rights in the context of law enforcement's access to personal data. It sets a precedent for access to personal data by authorities when combating offenses that are not classified as "serious" crimes, potentially lowering access barriers in less severe criminal investigations.

Case Overview: Case Name: Camera di Commercio, Industria, Artigianato e Agricoltura di Lecce v. Salvatore Manni Court: Second Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 9 March 2017 Reference: C-398/15 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 6(1)(e) of Directive 95/46/EC concerning data retention. Application of Article 3 of Directive 68/151/EEC regarding the accessibility of company registers. Balancing privacy rights under Articles 7 and 8 of the EU Charter against legal obligations of data disclosure for public interest. Core Facts: Salvatore Manni, a director whose personal data linked to a dissolved company’s insolvency, found in the company register, affected his business adversely. Manni sought to erase or anonymize his data from the register, arguing it was no longer necessary. The Chamber of Commerce, responsible for maintaining the register, appealed a lower court's order to do so. Judgment: Personal Data Retention: The court found that personal data in the register must remain accessible for an indefinite period due to ongoing public interest and legal certainty. Article 6(1)(e) of Directive 95/46/EC fundamentally limits the duration but allows exceptions based on the specific need. Access to Data: Member States must balance individual privacy rights against public disclosure requirements, potentially limiting access only in exceptional cases with compelling reasons. Applicable Law: Article 6(1)(e), Article 12(b), and Article 14 of Directive 95/46/EC Article 3 of Directive 68/151/EEC Reasoning: Necessity of Data Retention: Ensures legal certainty and transparency for third parties and creditors. Fundamental Rights Balance: Even though privacy is fundamental, business transparency and legal interests outweigh in this context. Case-by-Case Assessment: Member States can establish conditions under which data may be restricted based on individual cases. Impact: Affirms the necessity of public access to company registers for a long period even post-dissolution. Sets a precedent for potential data access limitations based on individual circumstances, maintaining a balance between privacy rights and public interest.

Case Overview: Case Name: BL v. MediaMarktSaturn Hagen-Iserlohn GmbH Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 25 January 2024 Reference: C-687/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of GDPR Articles 5, 24, 32, and 82. Right to compensation for non-material damage under GDPR. Definition and extent of "non-material damage." Core Facts: BL's personal data was mistakenly given to an unauthorized third party by Saturn employees. The unauthorized party returned the data within half an hour without allegedly becoming aware of the data itself. Judgment: Appropriateness of Measures: The accidental disclosure is not sufficient in itself to determine whether the technical and organizational measures by Saturn were inappropriate. Compensatory Function: The right to compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR is compensatory, not punitive. Severity and Compensation: The article does not require the consideration of infringement severity for the compensation amount. Burden of Proof: Claimant must prove both the infringement and the suffered damage. Non-material Damage: Mere fear of future misuse or abuse of personal data by an unauthorized party does not constitute non-material damage. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 5(1)(f), 24, 32(1)(b) and (2), 82(1). Reasoning: The court emphasized that mere disclosure of data does not automatically mean that security measures are inappropriate. Damage must be demonstrable and not purely hypothetical for compensation. Non-material damage includes genuine fears of misuse, but purely hypothetical fears are insufficient. Impact: Clarifies the scope of non-material damage and compensation entitlement under GDPR. Reinforces the need for claimants to provide concrete evidence of damage caused by data breaches. Sets a precedent for evaluating the appropriateness of security measures for data controllers.

Case Overview: Case Name: UI v. Österreichische Post AG Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 4 May 2023 Reference: C-300/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of the right to compensation under Article 82(1) GDPR. Conditions for awarding compensation for non-material damage under GDPR. Role of national rules in determining the extent of financial compensation. Core Facts: UI sought compensation from Österreichische Post AG for non-material damage caused by the processing of his data without consent, attributing him a political affinity. The Austrian Court required proof of damage beyond mere emotional upset. UI's case raised questions on the interpretation of Article 82 GDPR concerning damage and compensation. Judgment: Mere Infringement and Compensation: Mere infringement of GDPR provisions is insufficient for compensation; actual damage must be proven. Seriousness of Non-Material Damage: Compensation for non-material damage must not be subject to a threshold of seriousness. Any tangible non-material damage can be compensated regardless of its extent. National Rules on Financial Compensation: National courts must apply domestic rules to determine the amount of compensation, ensuring adherence to the principles of equivalence and effectiveness. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 82(1) Reasoning: Damage Requirement: Article 82(1) necessitates proof of actual damage beyond GDPR infringement alone. Broad Interpretation of Damage: The concept of damage in GDPR should be broadly interpreted to cover all tangible non-material harm. Consistency and Effectiveness: Ensures coherent application across Member States and full compensation for the damage suffered, upholding the principle of effectiveness. Impact: Clarifies conditions for the right to compensation under GDPR. Establishes that even minor non-material damage can warrant compensation. Ensures national rules on compensation comply with EU principles, reinforcing comprehensive data protection.

Concise Summary: Case Overview: Case Name: Michael Schwarz v Stadt Bochum Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Fourth Chamber) Date: 17 October 2013 Reference: C-291/12 Legal Issues: Legality and validity of Art. 1(2) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2252/2004, requiring biometric identification (fingerprints) in passports. Compatibility with fundamental rights under Art. 7 and 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights (respect for private life and protection of personal data). Proportionality and necessity of biometric data collection. Core Facts: Michael Schwarz was refused a passport by Stadt Bochum unless he provided fingerprints. Schwarz challenged the regulation demanding fingerprints, arguing it lacked legal basis and violated fundamental rights. The Verwaltungsgericht Gelsenkirchen referred the validity of the regulation to the CJEU. Judgment: Article 1(2) of Regulation No 2252/2004 is valid. The regulation has an appropriate legal basis under Article 62(2)(a) EC. The procedure for adopting the regulation did not violate procedural requirements. The inclusion of fingerprints in passports is justified, necessary, and proportionate in achieving the objectives of preventing passport falsification and fraudulent use. Applicable Law: Regulation (EC) No 2252/2004, amended by Regulation (EC) No 444/2009 Articles of the EU Charter: Articles 7, 8, and 52 Reasoning: Legal Basis: Regulation No 2252/2004 falls within the scope of Article 62(2)(a) EC. Fundamental Rights: Fingerprints constitute personal data and their processing interferes with rights under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter. However, this interference is justified by the regulation’s objectives. Proportionality: The measures are appropriate, necessary, and do not exceed what is required to prevent passport falsification and fraudulent use. Fingerprint storage is limited to the passport and protection against misuse is ensured. Impact: Confirms the legality and proportionality of biometric data in passports under EU law. Reinforces the balance between security measures and fundamental rights. Sets a precedent for future cases involving biometric data and privacy issues.

Case Overview: Case Name: Productores de Música de España (Promusicae) v. Telefónica de España SAU Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 29 January 2008 Reference: C-275/06 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of obligations regarding the retention and disclosure of traffic data to protect copyright in civil proceedings. Compatibility of privacy protections under the E-Privacy Directive with intellectual property rights under various EU Directives and fundamental rights under the EU Charter. Core Facts: Promusicae, a nonprofit representing music producers, requested personal data from Telefónica to identify users sharing copyrighted materials via a peer-to-peer network (KaZaA). Telefónica refused, citing national law (LSSI) which limits data disclosure to criminal cases or national security. Judgment: Data Retention and Disclosure: EU Directives (2000/31/EC, 2001/29/EC, 2004/48/EC, 2002/58/EC) do not require Member States to mandate disclosure of personal data for copyright protection in civil proceedings. Member States may legislate for such disclosure to protect copyright but are not compelled by EU law to do so. Balancing Fundamental Rights: The Directives need to be transposed in a way that balances privacy rights with intellectual property rights and effective judicial protection, ensuring no conflict with fundamental rights. Applicable Law: E-Privacy Directive (2002/58/EC), Information Society Directive (2000/31/EC), Copyright Directive (2001/29/EC), Enforcement Directive (2004/48/EC) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (Articles 7, 8, 17, 47) Reasoning: Fundamental Rights: The Court emphasized a fair balance between the right to privacy, property rights (including IP), and the right to an effective remedy is essential. Exceptions: Exceptions to data protection obligations must be proportionate and justified concerning national security, public security, and the investigation of criminal offenses, not extending to civil cases by default. Impact: This judgment clarifies that while national law can provide for data disclosure to protect copyrights in civil cases, it is not mandated by EU law. The decision underscores Member States' discretion in balancing privacy and property rights within the scope of the applicable EU legislation.

Case Overview: Case Name: Hauptpersonalrat der Lehrerinnen und Lehrer v. Minister des Hessischen Kultusministeriums Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 30 March 2023 Reference: C-34/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 88(1) and (2) of GDPR regarding processing of personal data in the employment context. Lawfulness of processing employees' personal data without their consent under GDPR. Core Facts: During the COVID-19 pandemic, the Ministry of Education for Hessen implemented live streaming of classes via videoconference without obtaining teachers' consent. The Principal Staff Committee contested this, arguing that teacher consent should be mandated. The Ministry defended the practice under national laws which they argued were specific rules under Article 88 of GDPR. Judgment: Interpretation of Article 88: National rules must meet the conditions of Article 88(2) to be considered ‘more specific rules’ under Article 88(1). Application of Incompatible National Provisions: If national provisions don't meet Article 88(2) requirements, they must be disregarded unless they form a valid legal basis under Article 6(3). Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 6(1)(c), 6(1)(e), 6(3), 88(1), 88(2) EU Charter: Article 7, Article 8 Reasoning: More specific rules under Article 88(1) must include protective measures specified in Article 88(2). National provisions merely reiterating GDPR principles without specific safeguards do not fulfill the criteria. Rules ensuring data processing conditions must not simply restate GDPR but offer additional, specific protection in the employment context. Impact: Clarifies the necessity for national rules to provide specific safeguards when processing employees' data. Establishes a benchmark for interpreting 'more specific rules' under GDPR. Limits national discretion when derogating GDPR provisions in the employment context.

Case Overview: Case Name: X v. Municipality of Residence Court: Eighth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 12 December 2013 Reference: C-486/12 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 12(a) of Directive 95/46/EC concerning right of access to personal data. Legality and reasonableness of fees charged for accessing personal data. Core Facts: X sought access to personal data from her municipality to contest a fine. Municipality provided a certified transcript and charged a fee of EUR 12.80. X contested the fee, arguing that no fee should be charged for accessing personal data. Judgment: Article 12(a) of Directive 95/46/EC: Does not preclude charging fees for accessing personal data, provided fees are not excessive. The fees should not exceed the cost of communicating the data. Verified by National Court: It is up to the national court to verify whether the fee is excessive based on the specific circumstances. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC, specifically Article 12(a) Article 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights Reasoning: Comparison of language versions clarified that Article 12(a) allows for fees as long as they are not excessive. Fees must strike a balance between protecting data subjects' privacy and the administrative burden on data controllers. Fees should not be an obstacle to exercising the right of access. Impact: Clarifies that data access under Directive 95/46/EC can involve reasonable fees. Sets a standard that fees must not exceed the cost of data communication, influencing future fee assessments by public authorities.

Case Overview: Case Name: Google Spain SL and Google Inc. v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 13 May 2014 Reference: C-131/12 Key Legal Issues: Definition of "processing of personal data" (Article 2(b) Directive 95/46/EC) Definition of "data controller" (Article 2(d) Directive 95/46/EC) Scope of territorial applicability (Article 4(1)(a) Directive 95/46/EC) Right to erasure and objection (Articles 12(b) and 14 Directive 95/46/EC) Balancing fundamental rights (Articles 7 and 8 EU Charter of Fundamental Rights) Core Facts: Mario Costeja González requested the removal of links to a newspaper article about his past debts, claiming it was no longer relevant. The Spanish Data Protection Agency (AEPD) ordered Google Spain and Google Inc. to remove these links from search results. Google Spain and Google Inc. contested this order, claiming they were not responsible for the data published by third parties. Judgment: Data Processing by Search Engines: The activity of indexing and displaying links by search engines constitutes processing of personal data (Article 2(b)). Google is considered the data controller in this context (Article 2(d)). Territorial Scope: Processing of personal data by Google falls under EU jurisdiction when carried out in the context of its advertising activities in the targeted Member State (Article 4(1)(a)). Right to Erasure: Individuals have the right to request search engines to remove links to personal data, even if the data remains on the original web pages and was lawfully published (Articles 12(b) and 14). Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(b), 2(d), 4(1)(a), 12(b), 14 EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 7 and 8 Reasoning: Importance of Privacy: Balancing the individual’s right to privacy against the public's interest in access to information. Responsibility of Search Engines: Given their role in disseminating information, search engines have a responsibility to ensure data processing complies with privacy protections. Impact: Establishes search engines’ responsibility in processing personal data. Strengthens the "right to be forgotten" within the EU, allowing individuals to request removal of outdated or irrelevant personal data from search engines. Sets a precedent for how data protection laws apply to digital intermediaries like search engines.

Case Overview: Case Name: Huber v. Bundesrepublik Deutschland Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 16 December 2008 Reference: C-524/06 Key Legal Issues: Protection of personal data (Directive 95/46/EC) Principle of non-discrimination on grounds of nationality (Article 12(1) EC) Necessity requirement for data processing (Article 7(e) of Directive 95/46/EC) Core Facts: Heinz Huber, an Austrian national, requested the deletion of his personal data from Germany's Central Register of Foreign Nationals (AZR), alleging discrimination as no similar database exists for German nationals. Huber argued that the data processing was unnecessary and unlawful under Directive 95/46/EC. Judgment: The Court held that the AZR may only contain data necessary for applying residence laws and must demonstrate that its centralised nature enables more effective application of these laws. Processing personal data for statistical purposes does not meet the necessity requirement under Article 7(e) of Directive 95/46/EC. The AZR’s data processing for crime-fighting purposes discriminates against non-German EU citizens and violates Article 12(1) EC. Applicable Law: Articles: 12(1) EC, 17 EC, 18 EC, 43 EC Directive 95/46/EC (Articles 1, 2, 3, 7(e)) Reasoning: The necessity requirement under Article 7(e) must be uniformly interpreted across Member States. Non-discrimination principle mandates that non-German EU citizens cannot be subjected to data processing that German nationals are exempt from. A Member State's crime-fighting objective does not justify discriminating data processing practices. Impact: Clarifies the data protection obligations under Directive 95/46/EC. Reinforces the principle of non-discrimination for EU citizens. Limits the scope of permissible data processing for statistical and crime-fighting purposes in the context of foreign nationals.

Case Overview: Case Name: WM and Sovim SA v. Luxembourg Business Registers Court: The Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 22 November 2022 Reference: C-37/20 and C-601/20 Key Legal Issues: Validity of Article 1(15)(c) of Directive 2018/843, which mandates public access to beneficial ownership information, under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. Interpretation of GDPR provisions in the context of public access to beneficial ownership data. Core Facts: WM and Sovim SA challenged the Luxembourg Business Registers' refusal to restrict public access to certain beneficial ownership details. They claimed that such access posed serious risks, including privacy infringement and potential violence or intimidation. Judgment: Public Access Invalid: Article 1(15)(c) of Directive 2018/843, mandating unrestricted public access to beneficial ownership information, was found invalid as it constituted a serious interference with the rights to privacy and data protection under Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter. The court deemed that such access was not strictly necessary for the objective of preventing money laundering and terrorist financing. Applicable Law: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 7, 8, 52 GDPR: Articles 5(1)(a)-(f), 25(2), 44-50 Directives: 2015/849 (as amended by 2018/843) Reasoning: Serious Interference: Public access to beneficial ownership data significantly infringes on privacy and data protection rights. Principle of Necessity: The court found that less intrusive means could achieve the anti-money laundering goals, such as limiting access to those with legitimate interest. Lack of Adequate Safeguards: The directive failed to balance adequately the objective of transparency against the protection of personal rights and did not include sufficient safeguards to prevent abuse. Impact: This judgment limits the extent to which beneficial ownership information can be made publicly accessible, potentially necessitating legislative amendments to align with privacy and data protection standards under EU law. It reinforces the need for measures that balance transparency and the protection of fundamental rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Volker und Markus Schecke GbR and Hartmut Eifert v. Land Hessen Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 9 November 2010 Reference: C-92/09 and C-93/09 Key Legal Issues: Right to protection of personal data (Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU) Validity of EU provisions requiring publication of personal data of beneficiaries of agricultural aid Interpretation of Articles 18 and 20 of Directive 95/46/EC Core Facts: Plaintiffs contested the publication of their data as beneficiaries of EU agricultural funds on a public website. Applications for aid included a statement informing applicants that their data would be published, as required by EU regulations. Plaintiffs sought to prevent the publication, arguing it violated their right to data protection. Judgment: Invalidity of EU Provisions: Articles 42(8b) and 44a of Regulation No. 1290/2005 and Regulation No. 259/2008 were declared invalid as they imposed an obligation to publish personal data without necessary distinctions (e.g., periods of aid, frequency, amount). The invalidity does not retroactively affect the already published data prior to the judgment. Applicable Law: EU Charter: Articles 7 and 8 Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 18 and 20 Regulation No. 1290/2005 (as amended by Regulation No. 1437/2007) Reasoning: The court found that the EU regulations failed to balance the need for transparency and public control with the fundamental rights to private life and data protection. The blanket publication of all beneficiaries without differentiation was deemed disproportionate. Impact: The decision invalidates the mandatory publication provisions for natural persons, ensuring future regulations must differentiate based on relevant criteria. It underscores the application of proportionality in data protection cases and establishes a precedent for handling the publication of personal data by public authorities. This case is relevant for issues involving the balance between transparency in public expenditure and individual data protection rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: La Quadrature du Net v. Premier ministre Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 6 October 2020 Reference: C-511/18, C-512/18, C-520/18 Key Legal Issues: - Legality of general and indiscriminate data retention in the context of national security and crime prevention. - Compatibility of national legislation with EU law, particularly Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, and Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC (ePrivacy Directive). Core Facts: - French and Belgian laws required electronic communications service providers to retain traffic and location data broadly for national security and public safety. - La Quadrature du Net and other parties challenged the laws, claiming they violated EU privacy standards. - The Grand Chamber addressed consolidated cases from the French Conseil d'État and the Belgian Constitutional Court. Judgment: 1. General Retention Prohibited: - Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC precludes legislative measures that mandate the general and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data. 2. Specific Conditions Permitting Data Retention: - Allowance for retention generally and indiscriminately during serious national security threats, subject to review and limited in time. - Targeted retention permissible if based on objective criteria, i.e., by geographical area or categories of persons implicated in serious crime or national security threats. - General retention of IP addresses and civil identity data permitted under strict conditions. 3. Access and Safeguards: - National regulations on automated data analysis and real-time data collection must be limited to strictly necessary situations and subject to effective prior judicial or administrative review. - Users must be notified when data is accessed unless it compromises ongoing investigations. 4. Effectiveness and Retrospective Application: - National courts cannot limit the temporal effects of a ruling that declares national data retention laws illegal. - Criminal courts need to disregard evidence obtained unlawfully under such laws if it prevents the accused from effectively contesting it. Applicable Law: - EU Law: - Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. - Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC (ePrivacy Directive). - Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation, GDPR). - National Law: - French Code de la sécurité intérieure. - Belgian Law on electronic communications. Reasoning: - Emphasizes the need to balance national security and crime prevention with the fundamental privacy rights of individuals. - Adequate safeguards and proportionality must be observed to ensure that data retention mechanisms do not disproportionately infringe on rights to privacy and data protection. Impact: - Clarifies the stringent conditions under which data retention by electronic communications providers can be legally mandated. - Provides specific guidelines for national courts and legislators in EU Member States regarding data retention laws in the context of national security and crime prevention. - Reinforces the principle of proportionality and necessity in national security legislation affecting privacy rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Österreichische Datenschutzbehörde and CRIF GmbH Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (First Chamber) Date: 4 May 2023 Reference: C-487/21 Key Legal Issues: - Interpretation of the term "copy" in Article 15(3) GDPR. - Scope of the data subject's right to obtain personal data and the context of the data processing. Core Facts: - F.F. requested CRIF GmbH to provide a copy of emails and database extracts containing his personal data. - CRIF GmbH provided only a summary of the personal data. - The Austrian Data Protection Authority (DSB) ruled in favor of CRIF GmbH, leading F.F. to appeal to the Federal Administrative Court, which referred questions to the Court of Justice. Judgment: - Definition of "Copy" Under Article 15(3) GDPR: - The term "copy" refers to a faithful and intelligible reproduction of all personal data undergoing processing. - This includes the right to obtain extracts from documents or entire documents where necessary to understand the context of data processing and to exercise the data subject's rights. - Definition of "Information" Under the Third Sentence of Article 15(3): - The term "information" is limited to the personal data that the controller must provide a copy of, as defined in the first sentence of Article 15(3). Applicable Law: - GDPR Articles: 4(1) (personal data definition), 15(1) (information for data subjects), 15(3) (right to a copy of personal data), 12(1) (transparency principle), and 12(3) (communication methods). - Recitals of GDPR: 10, 11, 26, 58, 60, and 63. Reasoning: - The context and objectives of Article 15 GDPR, aiming for transparency and the strengthening of data subject rights, necessitate providing a faithful copy covering all personal data. - The provision of contextual information may be essential for understanding the nature of the data and exercising rights effectively. - Balancing the right to access with the protection of others' rights and freedoms, such as intellectual property and trade secrets. Impact: - Clarifies the extent and scope of the right to access personal data under GDPR. - Emphasizes the necessity of providing comprehensible and contextually appropriate copies of personal data to data subjects. - Establishes clear guidelines on the balancing of access rights with third-party rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Institut professionnel des agents immobiliers (IPI) v. Geoffrey Englebert, Immo 9 SPRL, Grégory Francotte Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 7 November 2013 Reference: C-473/12 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of exceptions to the obligation to inform in data processing under Directive 95/46/EC (Articles 10, 11, 13(1)). Scope of these exceptions for private detectives acting on behalf of a regulated professional body. Compatibility of these exceptions with the principle of equality and non-discrimination under Article 6(3) TEU. Core Facts: IPI, a regulatory body for Belgian estate agents, used private detectives to gather evidence for proceedings against agents allegedly breaching professional rules. The legality of detectives' data collection without informing the subjects was challenged under Belgian law implementing Directive 95/46/EC. Judgment: Member State Options: Member States may but are not obligated to legislate exceptions to the obligation to inform data subjects under Articles 10 and 11 of Directive 95/46/EC, as specified in Article 13(1). Applicability to Private Detectives: The activities of private detectives acting for a professional body to investigate breaches of ethics in a regulated profession fall within the exception under Article 13(1)(d) of Directive 95/46/EC. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 10, 11, 13(1)(d) and (g) Directive 2002/58/EC: Article 15(1) TEU: Article 6(3) Reasoning: The Court emphasized the flexibility of Directive 95/46/EC, allowing Member States to determine the necessity of legislative measures restricting obligations to inform data subjects. The Court acknowledged the legitimate need for professional bodies like IPI to use private detectives to uphold professional standards. Impact: Clarifies the discretionary power of Member States under Directive 95/46/EC to impose or omit exceptions to the obligation of informing data subjects. Establishes a precedent for the permissible use of private detectives by regulatory bodies without informing data subjects, under specific conditions.

Case Overview: Case Name: Meta Platforms and Others v. Bundeskartellamt Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 4 July 2023 Reference: C-252/21 Key Legal Issues: - Intersection of GDPR compliance and competition law. - The role of consent and dominant market positions under data protection laws. - Lawfulness of processing sensitive categories of personal data. Core Facts: - Meta Platforms (formerly Facebook) processes user data across various services it owns (e.g., Instagram, WhatsApp), compiling detailed profiles for personalized advertising. - The German Federal Cartel Office prohibited Meta from certain data processing practices under its general terms, citing GDPR violations. - The case questions the interaction between data protection obligations under the GDPR and competition law enforcement. Judgment: - National Competition Authority's Role: - A competition authority can assess compliance with GDPR when examining potential abuse of dominance in breaches of competition law. - Obliged to cooperate with data protection authorities to ensure consistency. - Handling of Sensitive Data: - User data from websites/apps that reveal sensitive categories falls under GDPR’s prohibited processing unless specific derogations apply. - Consent Validity: - Consent to data processing must be freely given, especially relevant where the operator holds a dominant market position. Applicable Law: - GDPR Articles: 4(11), 6(1)(a)-(f), 7(4), 9(1)-(2), 51, 56 - TEU Article 4(3) - EU Charter: Articles 7, 8 Reasoning: - Competition authorities can examine data protection compliance to determine abuse of a dominant position. - For consent to be valid, especially under dominance, users must not be coerced into consenting as a pre-condition to using the service. - Meta Platforms’ data processing from its various services must be scrutinized under GDPR’s lawful processing provisions. Impact: - Ensures that data protection and competition laws are coherently applied. - Affirms the role of national competition authorities in assessing GDPR compliance, requiring cooperation with data protection authorities. - Clarifies the conditions under which data processing in online services, particularly in dominant market contexts, must operate.

Case Overview: Case Name: BE v. Nemzeti Adatvédelmi és Információszabadság Hatóság Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 12 January 2023 Reference: C-132/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of concurrent remedies under GDPR Articles 77(1), 78(1), and 79(1). Relationship between different types of legal remedies available under the GDPR. Application of Article 47 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights concerning the right to an effective remedy. Core Facts: BE, a shareholder, requested sound recordings from a company's general meeting, which the company partially fulfilled. BE filed a complaint with the Hungarian Data Protection Authority and simultaneously initiated court proceedings. The Hungarian authorities and the court delivered conflicting decisions regarding the same facts and potential GDPR violations. Judgment: Concurrent Remedies: The GDPR allows the remedies in Articles 77(1), 78(1), and 79(1) to be exercised concurrently and independently. Member States must ensure effective protection of rights and consistent application of GDPR provisions. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 77(1), 78(1), 79(1) EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Article 47 Relevant Recitals of GDPR: 10, 11, 141, 143 Reasoning: The GDPR text does not establish priority among the remedies. Ensuring effective protection of data subjects' rights requires allowing concurrent use of administrative and judicial remedies. Member States have procedural autonomy to determine the relationship between these remedies in national law while ensuring effectiveness and consistency. Impact: Clarifies that under the GDPR, data subjects can simultaneously use different legal avenues without hierarchy. Reinforces the principle that Member States must design procedural rules to facilitate effective and consistent application of GDPR rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Österreichischer Rundfunk and Others Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) Date: 20 May 2003 Reference: C-465/00, C-138/01, and C-139/01 Key Legal Issues: Compatibility of national legislation on income disclosure with EU data protection laws (Directive 95/46/EC). Right to privacy under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). Proportionality and necessity of data dissemination for public interest purposes. Core Facts: Various Austrian public bodies were required under national legislation (BezBegrBVG) to disclose income data of employees earning above a certain threshold for public audit and publication. Plaintiffs challenged the publication, arguing it violated Directive 95/46/EC and their right to privacy under Article 8 of ECHR. Judgment: Applicability of Directive 95/46: Directive 95/46/EC applies to the collection, processing, and transmission of income data. Lawfulness of Data Processing: National legislation does not preclude such data processing provided it is necessary and proportionate for the management of public funds. Direct Applicability: Articles 6(1)(c) and 7(c) and (e) of Directive 95/46/EC are directly applicable and can be invoked by individuals to challenge conflicting national laws. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 6(1)(c), 7(c), 7(e), and 13. ECHR: Article 8 (right to respect for private and family life). Reasoning: The court emphasized the need for a balance between public interest (transparent use of public funds) and individual privacy rights. The legality of interference with privacy under Article 8 ECHR requires the measure to be "necessary in a democratic society" and proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued. National courts must evaluate if broad disclosure of names and salaries meets these criteria or if more privacy-friendly alternatives could achieve the same objectives. Impact: Defines the scope of data protection in the context of public transparency obligations. Clarifies conditions under which personal data can be disclosed publicly in the interests of governmental and public accountability. Sets a precedent for national courts on balancing transparency with data protection rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Proximus NV v. Gegevensbeschermingsautoriteit Court: Fourth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 27 October 2022 Reference: C-129/21 Key Legal Issues: Consent requirement under E-Privacy Directive and GDPR for inclusion of personal data in public directories. Interpretation and application of the right to erasure ("right to be forgotten") under the GDPR. Controllers' responsibilities to ensure compliance with data protection laws and inform third-party controllers of consent withdrawals. Core Facts: Proximus, a telecom provider, included and disseminated a subscriber's contact details in public directories without renewed consent after the subscriber had opted out. The Belgian DPA fined Proximus €20,000 for GDPR infringements and ordered compliance measures, including updating databases and informing other directory providers of consent withdrawal. Judgment: Consent Requirement: Subscriber consent per GDPR Article 4(11) is necessary for including personal data in directories by providers other than the telecom operator. Consent may be provided to either the telecom operator or the directory provider. Right to Erasure: Subscriber requests for data withdrawal from directories constitute making use of the "right to erasure" under GDPR Article 17. Accountability and Communication: Providers must take suitable measures to inform third-party controllers and telecom operators of consent withdrawals, pursuant to GDPR Article 5(2) and Article 24. Reasonable Steps for Erasure: National authorities can order directory providers to take "reasonable steps" to inform search engine providers of erasure requests per GDPR Article 17(2). Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4(11), 5(2), 6(1)(a), 7(3), 17, 24, 95 E-Privacy Directive: Article 12(2), Article 2(f), Article 3 Reasoning: Emphasized GDPR's broad consent requirement for processing personal data in public directories. Highlighted the refusal of publishing incorrect data under rectification versus erasure. Acknowledged the necessity of communication between data controllers to ensure proper withdrawal of data processing based on consent. Impact: Clarifies the extent of consent needed under GDPR for public directory listings. Elevates the obligations on data controllers to manage and inform about consent withdrawals. Strengthens implementation of the right to erasure and accountability in data protection practices.

Case Overview: Case Name: X-FAB Dresden GmbH & Co. KG v. FC Court: Sixth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 9 February 2023 Reference: C-453/21 Key Legal Issues: Dismissal of DPO under Article 38(3) GDPR Conflict of interests under Article 38(6) GDPR Core Facts: FC was employed and served as the DPO for X-FAB and its related entities. X-FAB dismissed FC from his DPO role, citing possible conflict of interest with his other responsibilities (e.g., chairman of the works council). The employment contract of FC provided stricter conditions for dismissal under national law (BDSG). Judgment: Dismissal Conditions: National laws can impose stricter conditions for the dismissal of a DPO than those in GDPR, provided these conditions do not undermine GDPR objectives. Just cause for dismissal is valid even if unrelated to DPO tasks. Conflict of Interests: A DPO may be found in a conflict of interest if assigned other tasks that influence the objectives and methods of personal data processing. Determination of a conflict must be based on the specific circumstances of each case, including organizational structure and applicable rules. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 38(3), 38(6) Recitals 10, 97 German Law: Bundesdatenschutzgesetz (BDSG), Paragraphs 6, 38 Civil Code: Paragraph 626 Reasoning: Preserving Functional Independence: The court aims to ensure DPOs can perform their tasks independently and without undue influence. Compatibility with EU Law: National provisions must not conflict with the GDPR’s objectives of protecting personal data. Impact: Clarifies allowable conditions for dismissing DPOs under GDPR. Defines potential conflict of interest scenarios for DPOs holding multiple roles. Provides guidance for national courts assessing DPO dismissal and conflicts of interest.

Case Overview: Case Name: Bodil Lindqvist Court: Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 6 November 2003 Reference: C-101/01 Key Legal Issues: Definition of "processing of personal data" under Directive 95/46/EC (Article 3(1)). Scope and exceptions of Directive 95/46/EC (Article 3(2)). Definition of "personal data concerning health" (Article 8(1)). Interpretation of "transfer of data to a third country" (Article 25). Balancing data protection and freedom of expression. Core Facts: Bodil Lindqvist published personal data about her colleagues on her personal internet page without their consent. This included names, contact information, work conditions, hobbies, and medical information. Lindqvist was prosecuted under Swedish law implementing Directive 95/46/EC. Judgment: Processing of Personal Data: Referring to individuals by name and sharing personal details on the internet constitutes "processing of personal data wholly or partly by automatic means." Applicability of Exceptions: Such processing is not exempt under the exceptions in Article 3(2) of Directive 95/46. Health Data: Information about a colleague's injury and medical status is considered "personal data concerning health." Data Transfer: Loading data onto an internet page accessible globally does not constitute a "transfer [of data] to a third country" within the meaning of Article 25. Freedom of Expression: Directive 95/46 does not inherently restrict freedom of expression; national authorities must balance rights and interests. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 3(1), 3(2), 8(1), and 25 European Convention on Human Rights: Article 10 Reasoning: Broad definitions of "processing" and "personal data" within Directive 95/46/EC. Strict interpretation of exceptions to ensure effective data protection. Freedom of expression must be balanced against data protection in national applications. Impact: Clarifies the broad scope of data processing activities covered by EU data protection law. Reinforces the need for national courts to balance data protection with freedom of expression. Sets precedent for interpreting what constitutes a transfer of data to third countries in the context of the internet.

Case Overview: Case Name: GP v. juris GmbH Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 11 April 2024 Reference: C-741/21 Key Legal Issues: Right to compensation for data protection violations (Article 82(1) GDPR) Concept of 'non-material damage' within GDPR scope Liability exemptions for data controllers (Article 82(3) GDPR) Assessment of damages compensation (Article 82 versus Article 83 GDPR) Core Facts: GP, a lawyer, objected to juris GmbH using his data for direct marketing purposes. Despite his objections, juris continued to send him directed advertising. GP requested compensation under GDPR for material and non-material damages, specifically for the unauthorized use of his data. Judgment: Non-Material Damage: Infringement of data protection rights alone does not automatically constitute non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
