The affected individual must demonstrate actual damage, irrespective of its seriousness. Liability of Controller: Controllers cannot exempt themselves from liability by attributing the violation solely to the fault of their employees (Article 82(3) GDPR). Controllers must prove no accountability for the event causing the damage to be exempt from liability. Assessment of Damages: Criteria for setting administrative fines under Article 83 GDPR are not applicable to assessing compensation under Article 82. Compensation is based on actual damage suffered, without consideration of the number of infringements. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4, 21, 24, 25, 29, 32, 79, 82, 83 Recitals of GDPR: 85, 146, 148 Reasoning: Reinforces that demonstrated harm is essential for claims of non-material damage. Maintains strict accountability for controllers under Article 82, emphasizing high protection for data subjects. Differentiates the compensatory nature of Article 82 from the punitive function of Article 83. Impact: Clarifies the need for actual damage proof for non-material claims under GDPR. Strengthens the rigor around controller liability in data protection breaches. Ensures compensation focuses on actual damage without conflating with administrative penalty criteria.

Case Overview: - Case Name: Probst v. mr.nexnet GmbH - Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Third Chamber) - Date: 22 November 2012 - Reference: C-119/12 Key Legal Issues: - Interpretation of Article 6(2) and (5) of Directive 2002/58/EC concerning: - Processing of traffic data for billing and debt collection purposes. - Conditions under which traffic data can be processed by third parties acting under the authority of a service provider. Core Facts: - mr.nexnet GmbH, as assignee of claims from Verizon Deutschland GmbH, sought payment from Josef Probst for internet services. - Probst disputed the validity of the assignment contract under German law, triggering a reference to the CJEU for clarification on the applicable EU directive. Judgment: - Authorization of Data Transfer and Processing: - Article 6(2) and (5) of Directive 2002/58/EC authorizes service providers to pass traffic data to assignees for the purpose of debt collection. - Assignees can process traffic data provided they act under the service provider's authority and only handle data necessary for debt recovery. - Assignees must act on instructions from and under control of the service provider, ensuring compliance with data protection laws. Applicable Law: - Directive 2002/58/EC ("e-Privacy Directive"): Article 6(2) and (5) - Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 16, 17 (General data protection law) - German Law: Telecommunications Act (Telekommunikationsgesetz), Paragraph 97(1) Reasoning: - The court interpreted "under the authority" to mean that the assignee must act on the instructions and under the control of the service provider. - The contractual arrangements must ensure lawful processing and enable the service provider to verify compliance at all times. - This interpretation aligns with the objectives of protecting privacy and ensuring data security. Impact: - Clarifies Data Processor Responsibilities: - Service providers can delegate debt collection involving traffic data, provided robust contractual safeguards and supervisory controls are in place. - Reinforces the strict interpretation of data protection exceptions, emphasizing the need for explicit authority and oversight. This case is relevant for issues involving data protection in the context of debt collection by third parties under EU law directives.

Case Overview: Case Name: Scarlet Extended SA v. Société belge des auteurs, compositeurs et éditeurs SCRL (SABAM) Court: Court of Justice of the European Union, Third Chamber Date: 24 November 2011 Reference: C-70/10 Key Legal Issues: - Legality of imposing general monitoring obligations on ISPs. - Balance between protection of intellectual property rights and fundamental rights including data protection and freedom of expression. Core Facts: - SABAM sought an injunction requiring ISP Scarlet to install a system to filter and block files using peer-to-peer software to prevent copyright infringement. - Scarlet challenged the feasibility and legality of such a measure, arguing it would require general monitoring of all communications and infringe on user privacy. Judgment: - Such a general monitoring obligation for ISPs is prohibited under Article 15(1) of Directive 2000/31. - The court held that filtering systems infringe on the ISP's freedom to conduct business and user's rights to data protection and freedom of information. - The injunction would be costly and complicated, violating the fairness and proportionality requirement under Article 3(1) of Directive 2004/48. Applicable Law: - Directive 2000/31 (Electronic Commerce) - Directive 2001/29 (Copyright in the Information Society) - Directive 2004/48 (Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights) - Directive 95/46 (Data Protection) - Directive 2002/58 (E-Privacy) Reasoning: - The court emphasized that the measures must balance copyright protection with fundamental rights. - General monitoring obligations are not allowed as they conflict with EU directives ensuring data protection and freedom of communication. Impact: - Sets a precedent that ISPs cannot be compelled to undertake general monitoring of communications. - Reinforces the balance between enforcing intellectual property rights and safeguarding fundamental rights such as privacy and freedom of information.

Case Overview: Case Name: Google LLC v. Commission nationale de l’informatique et des libertés (CNIL) Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 24 September 2019 Reference: C-507/17 Key Legal Issues: - Interpretation of the right to de-referencing (Article 12(b) and Article 14(1) of Directive 95/46/EC, Article 17(1) of Regulation 2016/679). Core Facts: - CNIL fined Google EUR 100,000 for not applying a de-referencing request globally. - Google only removed links from European domain name extensions and implemented geo-blocking for users within Europe. Judgment: - Territorial Scope: - Google is not required to carry out de-referencing on all global versions of its search engine. - Required de-referencing must be done across all EU Member State versions. - Effective geo-blocking measures should be used to prevent access from within the EU. Applicable Law: - Directive 95/46/EC (Articles 12(b) and 14(1)) - Regulation 2016/679 (Articles 17(1), 56, 60-66, and 85) Reasoning: - No obligation in EU law for global de-referencing. - EU law aims for high-level data protection within the EU. - Considerations of global variations in fundamental rights balance (e.g., freedom of information). Impact: - Confirms that de-referencing requests under GDPR are limited to EU domains. - Clarifies the obligations of search engines regarding de-referencing and geo-blocking within the EU. - Potentially influences the approach to global data protection and the balance between privacy and freedom of information.

Case Overview: Case Name: Facebook Ireland and Schrems Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 16 July 2020 Reference: C-311/18 Key Legal Issues: - Validity of the Standard Contractual Clauses (SCC) and the EU-US Privacy Shield under GDPR Articles 7, 8, and 47. - Compliance of US surveillance laws with EU data protection standards. - Supervisory authorities' powers to suspend or prohibit data transfers based on SCCs. Core Facts: - Maximillian Schrems challenged Facebook Ireland’s transfer of his personal data to the US, arguing that US laws do not ensure adequate protection. - The Irish Data Protection Commissioner sought a preliminary ruling on the validity of the SCC Decision and the EU-US Privacy Shield. Judgment: Invalidation of the EU-US Privacy Shield: Reasoning: US laws, specifically under Section 702 of FISA and Executive Order 12333, do not provide limitations and safeguards ensuring an essentially equivalent level of protection to that of the EU. Additionally, the Ombudsperson Mechanism does not meet the standards for judicial redress required by Article 47 of the Charter. Impact: Transfers of personal data under the EU-US Privacy Shield are not compliant with GDPR, rendering the Privacy Shield invalid. Validity of the SCC Decision: Reasoning: SCCs include effective safeguards, enforceable rights, and mechanisms ensuring that data transfers can be suspended or prohibited if the receiving third country cannot comply with EU data protection requirements. Impact: SCCs remain a valid basis for data transfers, provided that entities assess third-country protections on a case-by-case basis and implement supplementary safeguards as needed. Applicable Law: - GDPR Articles 2(1), 46(1), 46(2)(c), 58(2)(f), 58(2)(j) - Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Articles 7 (Respect for private and family life), 8 (Protection of personal data), and 47 (Right to an effective remedy). Reasoning: - EU data transfers must maintain a level of protection essentially equivalent to that within the EU. - SCCs remain valid but need case-specific assessments and potential additional safeguards. - Supervisory authorities have a duty to act against non-compliant data transfers unless disallowed by a valid adequacy decision. Impact: - Strengthens the requirement for US legislative reform to ensure an adequate level of data protection equivalent to the EU for future adequacy decisions. - Reinforces the role of SCCs in data transfers, albeit with more stringent oversight by data controllers and supervisory authorities. The decision has far-reaching implications for data transfers between the EU and third countries, emphasizing the need for robust safeguards to align with EU data protection standards.

Case Overview: Case Name: ‘SS’ SIA v. Valsts ieņēmumu dienests Court: Fifth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 24 February 2022 Reference: C-175/20 Key Legal Issues: GDPR Scope and Definitions (Articles 2, 4) Data Processing Principles (Article 5) Lawfulness of Processing (Article 6) Limitations on Rights (Article 23) Core Facts: The Latvian tax authorities requested significant amounts of personal data from ‘SS’ SIA, a provider of internet advertisement services, regarding vehicle sale advertisements. The request aimed to identify taxpayers who might not have declared sales for tax purposes. Judgment: Applicability of GDPR: The collection of personal data by tax authorities from an economic operator is subject to GDPR requirements, especially Article 5(1) principles on data processing. No Broad Derogation Authority: Tax authorities cannot override Article 5(1) GDPR provisions without specific legislative measures enabling such a derogation under Article 23(1). Conditional Data Requests: Tax authorities can require information from internet service providers if the data are necessary for the specified purposes and the collection period is limited to what is strictly necessary to achieve the public interest objective. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 2, 4, 5(1), 6, 23(1) Reasoning: Emphasizes proportionality and necessity in data collection for public interest tasks. Highlights the requirement of legislative authorization for any deviation from GDPR principles. Impact: Clarifies limitations on the powers of tax authorities under GDPR. Reinforces the necessity and proportionality criteria for data collection in the public interest. Establishes that specific legislative measures are essential for derogation from GDPR principles by public authorities.

Case Overview: Case Name: Gesamtverband Autoteile-Handel eV v. Scania CV AB Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 9 November 2023 Reference: C-319/22 (Scania) Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Art. 61(1) & (2) Regulation (EU) 2018/858: Obligation on vehicle manufacturers to make repair and maintenance information easily accessible. Application of GDPR Art. 6(1)(c): Processing of personal data (VINs) as a legal obligation for vehicle manufacturers. Core Facts: Gesamtverband, representing vehicle parts wholesalers, claimed Scania did not provide adequate access to vehicle repair and maintenance information. Scania provided manual access to certain data but restricted VIN access and automated data processing. Judgment: Scope of Information Obligation: The requirement to present information in an easily accessible, machine-readable format covers all vehicle repair and maintenance information, not just spare parts data. Database Interface: Manufacturers are not required to create a searchable database interface but must provide data in a machine-readable format for direct electronic processing. Availability of VINs: Manufacturers must establish a searchable database for parts information accessible using the VIN and additional criteria. Legal Obligation Under GDPR: Article 61 constitutes a legal obligation under GDPR to process VINs to provide necessary data to independent operators. Applicable Law: Regulation (EU) 2018/858: Articles 3, 4, 61, Annex X. GDPR: Articles 4(1), 4(7), 6(1)(c), 6(3). Reasoning: Ensuring Competition: Facilitating effective competition in repair and maintenance services necessitates detailed access to vehicle data. Legal Basis Under GDPR: Requirement to provide VINs meets the criteria of lawfulness, defining purpose, and public interest objectives under GDPR. Data Processing Format: Data must be accessible in structured formats conducive to direct electronic use. Impact: Clarifies manufacturers' obligations to provide comprehensive and accessible repair and maintenance data in machine-readable formats. Reinforces legal requirements for data processing under GDPR concerning vehicle identification numbers (VINs) for independent operators. Promotes transparency and competition in the vehicle repair and maintenance services market.

Case Overview: Case Name: Ligue des droits humains v. Conseil des ministres Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 21 June 2022 Reference: C-817/19 Key Legal Issues: Validity of PNR Directive in light of Articles 7, 8, and 52(1) of the EU Charter. Applicability of GDPR to PNR data processing. Interpretation of the scope of the PNR Directive (applying to intra-EU flights). Compatibility of extended data retention periods with the EU Charter. Authority to approve data post six months and its compliance with the directive. Implications for the free movement of persons within the EU. Core Facts: Belgian Law of 25 December 2016 transposed the PNR Directive, API Directive, and Directive 2010/65, extending PNR data collection to various transport sectors including intra-EU flights. Data was processed for purposes beyond the PNR Directive’s scope, including activities of intelligence and security services. Judgment: GDPR Applicability: GDPR applies to PNR data processing by private operators but not to processing by public authorities under the PNR Directive for law enforcement purposes. Validity of PNR Directive: The PNR Directive is valid under the EU Charter, provided it meets strict necessity and proportionality requirements. Purposes of PNR Data Processing: PNR data can only be processed for the prevention, detection, investigation, and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crimes—no other purposes. Data Retention: General retention period of five years for PNR data is impermissible without evidence of risk related to terrorist offenses or serious crimes. Data Disclosure Authority: The PIU cannot approve the disclosure of PNR data after six months; it must be approved by a judicial or equally independent authority. Free Movement Implications (Article 45 of the Charter): National legislation extending the PNR system to intra-EU transport operations can infringe on free movement unless strictly necessary and proportionate. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles 2(2)(d), 4, 23 PNR Directive Articles 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 12 EU Charter Articles 7, 8, 21, 45, 52 TEU Article 3(2) TFEU Articles 67(2) Reasoning: The PNR Directive must be interpreted to align with the fundamental rights under the Charter. Automated processing and retention must have strict safeguards to protect against disproportionate interference with personal data. Impact: National laws extending PNR data collection and processing need to comply strictly with the proportionality and necessity principles to safeguard fundamental rights. Retention and processing of PNR data are restricted to specific, legitimate purposes. This case clarifies the scope and limitations of the PNR Directive, emphasizes the protection of fundamental rights, and insists on strict proportionality in laws impacting data privacy and the free movement of persons.

Case Overview: - Case Name: RW v. Österreichische Post AG - Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union - Date: 12 January 2023 - Reference: C-154/21 Key Legal Issues: - Interpretation of data subject's right of access to personal data under Article 15(1)(c) of the GDPR. - Obligation to disclose the actual identity of data recipients vs. categories of recipients. Core Facts: - RW requested access to personal data and information about specific recipients from Österreichische Post. - Österreichische Post provided only categories of recipients, not specific identities. - RW sought legal action to obtain specific identities of data recipients. Judgment: - The Court ruled that the data subject's right of access under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR includes an obligation for the data controller to provide the actual identity of the recipients to whom personal data have been or will be disclosed. - If it is impossible to identify those recipients or if requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, the controller may provide categories of recipients instead. Applicable Law: - General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Articles: 5(1)(a), 12(5), 15(1)(c), 21 - Recitals of GDPR: 4, 9, 10, 39, 63, 74 Reasoning: - Emphasizes the principle of transparency, requiring clear and accessible information about data processing. - Clarifies that the right of access extends to specific recipient identities unless it is impracticable or the requests are excessive or unfounded. - Ensures the effectiveness of other GDPR rights like rectification, erasure, restriction of processing, and objection. Impact: - Confirms that data controllers must provide specific identities of data recipients when requested, enhancing transparency and data subject rights. - Provides clarity on the balance between data subject rights and practical limitations on data controller obligations.

Case Overview: Case Name: Bonnier Audio v. Perfect Communication Sweden (ePhone) Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Third Chamber) Date: 19 April 2012 Reference: C-461/10 Key Legal Issues: - Application of Data Retention Directive (2006/24/EC) versus E-Privacy Directive (2002/58/EC) - Interpretation of Directive 2004/48/EC on the enforcement of intellectual property rights Core Facts: - Bonnier Audio and others held exclusive rights to reproduce and distribute 27 audio books. - The audio books were allegedly distributed without consent via an FTP server using an IP address provided by ePhone. - Bonnier Audio sought an injunction requiring ePhone to disclose the identity of the subscriber linked to the IP address. Judgment: - Data Retention Directive (2006/24/EC) does not preclude national laws allowing ISPs to disclose user identity for civil claims concerning IP infringements. - Directive 2006/24 solely addresses data retention for crime investigation by public authorities, thus not applicable here. - National law allowing such disclosure does not violate EU Directives 2002/58/EC and 2004/48/EC, provided a fair balance between IP rights and personal data protection is maintained. Applicable Law: - Directives: 2006/24/EC, 2004/48/EC, 2002/58/EC - Articles: 3-5, 11 of Directive 2006/24; Article 8 of Directive 2004/48 Reasoning: - Directive 2006/24 aims at crime investigation, not civil IP disputes. - Disclosure in civil proceedings requires clear evidence of IP infringement and adherence to proportionality principles. - National courts must evaluate the conflicting interests and ensure balanced application. Impact: - Confirms national courts can order ISPs to disclose subscriber data in IP infringement suits under specific conditions. - Reinforces the non-applicability of criminal data retention rules to civil IP disputes. - Emphasizes proportionality and balance in applying confidentiality and data protection laws.

Case Overview: Case Name: Jehovan todistajat v. Tietosuojavaltuutettu Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 10 July 2018 Reference: C-25/17 Key Legal Issues: Material scope of Directive 95/46/EC—Household exemption and criminal offence/public security exemption (Article 3(2)). Definition of a "personal data filing system" (Article 2(c)). Definition of "data controller" (Article 2(d)). Concept of "joint controllers" (Article 4 GDPR). Intersection of data protection and freedom of religion (Article 10(1) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU). Core Facts: Members of the Jehovah’s Witnesses religious community collected personal data during door-to-door preaching without adhering to Finnish data protection laws. The data included names, addresses, and information about individuals' beliefs and family circumstances. The Finnish Data Protection Board prohibited the community from collecting or processing data without legal compliance, leading to legal action by the community. Judgment: Household Exemption Inapplicable: Door-to-door preaching and data collection do not fall under the purely personal or household activity exemption (Article 3(2), second indent of Directive 95/46). Personal Data Filing System: The collection qualifies as a "filing system" because it enables data to be easily retrieved according to specific criteria, even without formal lists or data sheets (Article 2(c)). Joint Data Controller: The Jehovah’s Witnesses Community is a joint controller along with its preaching members, even if it does not access the data, due to its role in organizing and coordinating the activity (Article 2(d) and the concept of joint controllers in GDPR). Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(c), 2(d), and 3(2) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Article 10(1) EU GDPR: Article 4 Reasoning: Broad definition of "controller" and "filing system" to ensure comprehensive data protection. Activities being structured and coordinated by the community implicates it as a joint controller. The right to religious freedom does not override compliance with data protection laws. Impact: Expands the interpretation of what constitutes a "data filing system" and the scope of joint controllership under EU data protection laws. Clarifies that religious activities involving public interaction are not exempt from data protection regulations. Emphasizes broad applicability of data protection rules irrespective of the specific format in which personal data is structured.

Case Overview: Case Name: Wirtschaftsakademie Schleswig-Holstein GmbH v. Unabhängiges Landeszentrum für Datenschutz Schleswig-Holstein Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) Date: 5 June 2018 Reference: C-210/16 Key Legal Issues: Definition of "controller" under Directive 95/46/EC. Application of national law and competence of national supervisory authorities. Joint responsibility in data processing under data protection law. Core Facts: Wirtschaftsakademie operated a Facebook fan page. The Independent Data Protection Center of Schleswig-Holstein (ULD) ordered Wirtschaftsakademie to deactivate the page due to non-compliance with data protection laws, as Facebook collected data via cookies without informing visitors. Wirtschaftsakademie argued it was not responsible for Facebook's data collection and processing. Judgment: Administrator as Controller: The CJEU ruled that the administrator of a Facebook fan page does fall within the definition of a "controller" under Article 2(d) of Directive 95/46/EC. The administrator is jointly responsible with Facebook for the data processing of visitors to its fan page. National Supervisory Authority's Power: The CJEU held that national supervisory authorities in one Member State can exercise powers under Article 28(3) of Directive 95/46/EC against establishments in their territory. This holds even if another establishment in a different Member State has exclusive responsibility for data processing within the EU. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(d), 4(1)(a), 17(2), 24, 28(3), (6) Recitals 10, 18, 19, 26 EU Charter: Article 8(3) Reasoning: Broad Definition of "Controller": Aims to ensure effective protection of individuals' data rights. Joint Responsibility: Even if administrators lack direct data access, their actions contribute to data processing. Independence of Supervisory Authorities: Ensures national authorities can independently assess and act on data protection violations. Impact: Clarifies joint responsibility in data processing for social network page administrators. Expands the scope of national supervisory authorities' powers. Ensures broad and effective protection of personal data across the EU.

Concise Summary: Case Overview: - Case Name: Facebook Ireland Ltd et al. v. Gegevensbeschermingsautoriteit - Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) - Date: 15 June 2021 - Reference: C-645/19 Key Legal Issues: - Competence of national supervisory authorities (SAs) under the GDPR (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) - Application of the ‘one-stop shop’ mechanism and ‘lead supervisory authority’ (Articles 55-58 and 60-66 GDPR) - Interpretation of Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (Articles 7, 8, and 47) Core Facts: - The Belgian Data Protection Authority (DPA) launched injunction proceedings against Facebook for alleged data protection violations using cookies, social plug-ins, and pixels. - Facebook claimed that under the GDPR 'one-stop shop' mechanism, only the Irish Data Protection Commissioner had jurisdiction since Facebook Ireland is the main establishment. Judgment: - Jurisdiction of Non-Lead SA: A non-lead SA (like the Belgian DPA) can exercise its power to bring legal proceedings under Article 58(5) GDPR in cases where it has competence to adopt decisions on data processing breaches, provided cooperation and consistency mechanisms are respected. - No Main Establishment Requirement: The jurisdiction of a non-lead SA to initiate proceedings does not require the data controller to have its main establishment or another establishment in the member state of that SA. - Applicability of GDPR: The competence of SAs under GDPR applies to ongoing proceedings if based on post-25 May 2018 facts—when GDPR became applicable—subject to adherence to cooperation mechanisms. - Direct Effect of GDPR: Article 58(5) GDPR has direct effect, allowing an SA to bring actions against private entities even in absence of specific national implementation. Applicable Law: - GDPR Articles: 3, 4, 51, 55, 56-58, 60-66, 77-79 - Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 7, 8, 47 Reasoning: - Ensures consistent and high-level protection of personal data as fundamental rights (Article 16 TFEU and GDPR). - Emphasizes sincere and effective cooperation between the lead SA and other SAs in the 'one-stop shop' mechanism. - Clarification that procedural rules generally apply from the date they come into force unless specified otherwise. Impact: - Clarifies that non-lead SAs may initiate legal proceedings under GDPR against data controllers/processors located within or outside their own member state. - Reinforces the ‘one-stop shop’ mechanism's function and the necessity of cross-SA cooperation. - Affirms that GDPR provisions have direct applicability, enabling SAs to enforce GDPR even without national legislative measures.

Case Overview: Case Name: Direktor na Glavna direktsia Natsionalna politsia pri MVR Sofia Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 30 January 2024 Reference: C-118/22 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of data minimisation and storage limitation under Article 4(1)(c) and (e) Directive (EU) 2016/680. Right to erasure and restriction of processing under Article 16(2) and (3) Directive (EU) 2016/680. Compatibility of national legislation with proportionality principle under Article 52(1) EU Charter. Core Facts: NG, after being legally rehabilitated post-conviction, requested erasure of his data from Bulgarian national police records. The request was denied, citing Bulgarian law that stores data of convicted individuals until their death unless specific conditions apply. NG challenged this, arguing indefinite data storage infringed Directive 2016/680. Judgment: Overruled indefinite data storage: National legislation is precluded if it stipulates storage of personal data until the individual's death without periodic review. Imposed obligations on data controllers: Police authorities must periodically review the necessity of data storage. Data subjects must be granted rights to erasure and restriction of processing when data retention is no longer necessary. Applicable Law: Directive (EU) 2016/680: Articles 4(1)(c) and (e), 5, 10, 13(2)(b), 16(2) and (3). EU Charter: Articles 7 (Respect for private life) and 8 (Protection of personal data). Reasoning: Principle of proportionality: Data retention must be strictly necessary and periodically reviewed. Data minimisation: Law must ensure data is adequate, relevant, and not excessive. Protection of sensitive data: Enhanced safeguards for biometric and genetic data. Impact: Clarifies limits on data retention periods for law enforcement. Enhances data subjects' rights to erasure and processing restrictions. Ensures national laws align with EU data protection and fundamental rights principles.

Case Overview: Case Name: Ministerstvo na vatreshnite raboti Court: Fifth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 26 January 2023 Reference: C-205/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Directive 2016/680 on the processing of biometric and genetic data. Requirement for lawful processing under EU law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, specifically Articles 47 (Right to an Effective Remedy) and 48 (Presumption of Innocence). Core Facts: V.S. refused to consent to the collection of her biometric and genetic data after being accused in criminal proceedings for participating in a criminal organization. The Bulgarian police sought judicial enforcement for compulsory data collection under national law, which references the GDPR instead of Directive 2016/680. The Bulgarian court questioned whether this approach met EU law requirements and sought guidance from the EU court. Judgment: Compliance with Directive 2016/680: The processing of biometric and genetic data must be "strictly necessary" and authorized by clear and precise national law. National law referencing the GDPR, instead of Directive 2016/680, does not automatically invalidate such processing if the law sufficiently clarifies that it falls within the Directive’s scope. Systematic collection of data for all accused persons without specific necessity violates the Directive. Judicial Review: National law must ensure judicial review guaranteeing effective protection under Article 47 of the Charter. Courts must ensure the conditions for accusation are subsequently reviewed, respecting the right to be presumed innocent. Applicable Law: Directive 2016/680 Articles: 4(1)(a)-(c), 6(a), 8(1)-(2), 10. GDPR Articles: 9(1)-(4), 19. Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Articles 7, 8, 47, 48, 52. Reasoning: Emphasized strict necessity for processing sensitive data and requirement for clear legal authorization. Affirmed judicial obligations to ensure effective remedy and presumption of innocence while maintaining national security and crime prevention. Impact: Clarifies the interpretation of data processing laws in criminal contexts. Emphasizes the need for clear, precise national laws authorizing data processing. Ensures judicial oversight in balancing crime prevention with fundamental rights protections.

Case Overview: Case Name: Bundesrepublik Deutschland v. SpaceNet AG and Telekom Deutschland GmbH Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 20 September 2022 Reference: C-793/19 Key Legal Issues: General and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data. Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC. Compliance with EU Charter rights (Articles 7, 8, 11, 52). Core Facts: German legislation mandated telecom providers to retain traffic and location data of users for 10 weeks. Providers argued this violates EU law and fundamental privacy rights. Judgment: Retention of Data: The court ruled that general and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data for combating serious crime is precluded by EU law. Targeted retention based on objective criteria and limited retention of specific data (e.g., IP addresses) is permissible under strict safeguards. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC (E-privacy Directive) EU Charter: Articles 7 (Respect for private and family life), 8 (Protection of personal data), 11 (Freedom of expression and information), 52 (Scope of guaranteed rights) Reasoning: Proportionality and Necessity: Emphasized need for targeted retention measures that are strictly necessary. General retention measures overly invasive and not proportionate to objectives. Rights Balancing: Necessitated balancing between combating crime and protecting fundamental rights. General retention of data must be exceptional and time-limited for specific serious threats. Impact: Clarifies limits on data retention under EU law. Affirms stringent requirements for lawful data retention by telecom providers. Establishes legal framework prioritizing privacy and proportionality in data retention practices.

Case Overview: Case Name: Joined Cases C-203/15 and C-698/15 (Tele2 Sverige AB and Secretary of State for the Home Department v. Tom Watson, Peter Brice, Geoffrey Lewis) Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) Date: 21 December 2016 Reference: C-203/15 and C-698/15 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC regarding the general and indiscriminate retention of traffic and location data. Privacy rights under Articles 7, 8, and 11 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Scope and requirements for lawful access to retained data by national authorities. Core Facts: Tele2 Sverige ceased data retention following the decision invalidating Directive 2006/24. Meanwhile, Tom Watson and others challenged the UK's Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act 2014. Both cases questioned the legality of national laws requiring telecom providers to retain and offer access to citizens' electronic communications data for law enforcement purposes. Judgment: Preclusion of General and Indiscriminate Retention: National laws mandating the general and indiscriminate retention of all traffic and location data are precluded by Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58, as they infringe on the rights to privacy and protection of personal data under the Charter. Access to Data: Access by national authorities must be strictly limited to the fight against serious crime, subject to prior review by judicial or independent administrative authority, and data must be retained within the EU. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC (E-Privacy Directive) EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52(1) Reasoning: Strict Interpretation: Article 15(1) allows derogation from confidentiality principles only if measures are strictly necessary and proportionate. Fundamental Rights: Retention measures infringe the rights to private life, data protection, and freedom of expression. Proportionality: Blanket data retention is neither strictly necessary nor proportionate to the objectives of fighting serious crime. Impact: Sets a higher threshold for data retention laws under EU law. Demands targeted, specific, and proportionate retention measures to support law enforcement without broadly infringing civil liberties. Ensures stronger safeguards and oversight mechanisms for accessing retained data.

Case Overview: Case Name: Leistritz AG v. LH Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (First Chamber) Date: 22 June 2022 Reference: C-534/20 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of the second sentence of Article 38(3) of the GDPR. Whether national law can impose stricter conditions for terminating a data protection officer (DPO) than those provided by GDPR. Core Facts: LH, a Data Protection Officer (DPO) at Leistritz AG, had her employment contract terminated due to restructuring. German law stipulates that a DPO’s employment can only be terminated with just cause, even if unrelated to their tasks as DPO. The Federal Labour Court of Germany sought a preliminary ruling on whether this national law conflicts with EU law. Judgment: The court ruled that the second sentence of Article 38(3) GDPR does not preclude member states from having stricter rules for terminating a DPO’s employment, provided these do not undermine GDPR objectives. National legislation requiring just cause for termination, even if unrelated to DPO tasks, is permissible. Applicable Law: GDPR Article 38(3) – Protection against dismissal or penalties for performing DPO tasks. German Civil Code – Protection laws for DPO employment contracts. Reasoning: The court emphasized that GDPR aims to protect DPO independence and ensure high-level protection of personal data. National laws can offer higher protection if they align with GDPR objectives and do not prevent the termination for failure to meet professional standards. Impact: Clarifies that GDPR allows member states to have more stringent protective measures for terminating DPOs. Ensures that enhanced national protections do not conflict with the fundamental aims of GDPR, particularly the DPO’s functional independence.

Case Overview: Case Name: Pankki S Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 22 June 2023 Reference: C-579/21 Key Legal Issues: Scope of the right of access under GDPR Article 15(1). Definition of "personal data" under Article 4(1) GDPR. Application of GDPR to actions preceding its effective date (Article 99(2) GDPR). Core Facts: J.M. requested Pankki S to disclose information about who accessed his personal data. Pankki S refused, arguing that such information constitutes personal data of the employees. J.M. sought annulment of this decision, raising the issue of his rights under GDPR Article 15(1). Judgment: Right of Access Applicability: Article 15 GDPR applies even to data processed before its applicability date if the request is made after GDPR came into effect. The right of access includes obtaining information on the dates and purposes for which personal data was accessed. Limits to Right of Access: Information on the identity of employees who conducted the data access is not covered unless essential to exercise specific rights under GDPR, considering employees' rights. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4(1), 15(1), 99(2) Recitals: 4, 10, 11, 26, 39, 58, 60, 63, 74 Reasoning: Context and Purpose: The broad scope of ‘personal data’ includes any information available from data processing, critical for evaluating the lawfulness of data processing. Balance of Interests: Right of access must be balanced against the rights and freedoms of employees; direct identifiers may be withheld unless necessary to assert rights under GDPR. Impact: Establishes importance of transparency and accountability under GDPR. Clarifies the scope and limitations of the right of access and the definition of personal data under GDPR. Fortifies the procedural application of GDPR to activities dating back before its implementation but requested access after GDPR became effective.

Case Overview: Case Name: VD Court: The Court of Justice of the European Union (Grand Chamber) Date: 20 September 2022 Reference: C-339/20 Key Legal Issues: Legality of general and indiscriminate retention of traffic data by electronic communications services to combat market abuse, including insider dealing. Access to retained data by financial authorities without prior judicial review. Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC in conjunction with Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52(1) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. Core Facts: VD and SR were under investigation for insider dealing and related offenses. Traffic data obtained by the French financial market authority (AMF) was used as evidence. The data was retained under national legislation that imposed a general retention obligation on telecommunications operators. Judgment: General and Indiscriminate Data Retention: Such retention for combating market abuse, including insider dealing, is precluded under EU law. The national legislation that demanded one-year retention of all traffic data without differentiation violates Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58, as interpreted in light of the Charter. Data Access Without Judicial Review: Access to retained data by financial authorities without prior judicial or independent administrative review is incompatible with EU law. Restriction on Temporal Effects: National courts cannot restrict the temporal effects of the invalidation of incompatible national legislation. The invalidity applies immediately and the data previously retained under such provisions cannot be used as evidence. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC (Article 15(1)) Directive 2003/6/EC (Article 12(2)(a) and (d)) Regulation No 596/2014 (Article 23(2)(g) and (h)) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (Articles 7, 8, 11, and 52(1)) Reasoning: The general and indiscriminate retention of traffic data infringes the fundamental rights to respect for private life and protection of personal data. Adequate safeguards against abuse and necessity for stricter measures in serious cases must be present. Any deviation from the direct effect of EU laws by national courts undermines the primacy and uniform application of EU law. Impact: Reinforces the limitations on data retention obligations imposed on electronic communications services under EU law. Affirms that financial authorities require judicial oversight to access retained telecommunication data. Sets a precedent for immediate application of invalidation of incompatible national provisions, impacting ongoing and future criminal proceedings.

Case Overview: Case Name: Digi Távközlési és Szolgáltató Kft. v. Nemzeti Adatvédelmi és Információszabadság Hatóság Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 20 October 2022 Reference: C-77/21 Key Legal Issues: Principle of Purpose Limitation (Article 5(1)(b) GDPR) Principle of Storage Limitation (Article 5(1)(e) GDPR) Further processing of personal data and its compatibility with initial collection purposes Retention period of personal data in accordance with GDPR principles Core Facts: Digi, an internet service provider, created a test database from an existing database to address technical issues. Personal data from the primary database were copied and retained, leading to a data breach. The Hungarian Data Protection Authority fined Digi for not adhering to the GDPR principles of purpose and storage limitation. Judgment: Purpose Limitation: Creating a test database for error correction is permissible if further processing is compatible with original purposes considering criteria in Article 6(4) GDPR. Storage Limitation: Retention of personal data in the test database is limited to the period necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4(2), 5(1)(b), 5(1)(e), 6(1)(b), 6(4), 89(1) Recitals of GDPR: 10, 50 Reasoning: Further Processing Compatibility: Assesses specific link between the initial data collection purposes and further processing, as per Article 6(4) GDPR. Evaluates nature of data, context, potential consequences, and safeguards in processing. Retention Necessity: Emphasizes data retention no longer than necessary for specific purposes of tests and corrections. Impact: Clarifies the requirements for compatible further processing under the purpose limitation principle. Reinforces strict adherence to necessary data retention periods in line with storage limitation. Provides criteria to assess further processing compatibility, ensuring a high level of data protection compliance under GDPR.

Case Overview: Case Name: FT v. DW Court: First Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 26 October 2023 Reference: C-307/22 Key Legal Issues: Right to obtain a first copy of personal data free of charge (Article 12(5), Article 15(3) GDPR) Interpretation of reasons for requesting access to data (Recital 63 GDPR) Requirements for providing copies of medical records (Article 23(1)(i) GDPR) Core Facts: DW requested a free copy of medical records from dentist FT, suspecting malpractice. FT refused, citing costs reimbursement under national law (Paragraph 630g BGB, Germany). DW sued FT, claiming this right under GDPR. Judgment: Obligation to Provide Free Copy: Controllers must provide a first copy of personal data free of charge regardless of the request’s purpose. Privacy reasons in Recital 63 GDPR do not restrict this right. Economic Interests of Controllers: National laws protecting controllers' economic interests do not justify denying the free first copy. Only measures protecting others’ rights/freedoms can justify restrictions under Article 23(1)(i) GDPR. Scope of Data Provided: In doctor-patient context, data subjects are entitled to a complete, intelligible copy of medical records. This includes all personal data such as diagnoses and treatment details. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4(1), 12(5), 15(1), 15(3), 23(1)(i) Recital 63 GDPR German Civil Code (BGB) Paragraph 630g Reasoning: Article 15 GDPR grants broad access rights, aiming for transparency and data protection. Restrictions based purely on economic interests are impermissible under GDPR. The data subject's right to a complete copy ensures the ability to verify data accuracy and lawfulness. Impact: Strengthens the interpretation of the GDPR regarding data access rights. Clarifies the limitation on national laws that conflict with GDPR provisions. Enhances transparency requirements for healthcare providers handling personal data.

Case Overview: Case Name: VQ v. Land Hessen Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 9 July 2020 Reference: C-272/19 Key Legal Issues: Definition of "Data Controller" under GDPR (Article 4(7)) Applicability of GDPR Right of Access (Article 15) Scope of GDPR regarding activities outside Union law (Article 2(2)(a)) Core Facts: VQ applied to the Petitions Committee of Land Hessen's parliament for access to his personal data under GDPR. The Parliament President rejected the application, claiming GDPR does not apply to parliamentary activities. VQ challenged this decision, leading to a preliminary ruling request on the applicability of GDPR in this context. Judgment: The Petitions Committee as Data Controller: The Petitions Committee of the parliament is considered a data controller under Article 4(7) of GDPR if it determines the purposes and means of data processing. Processing of personal data by this committee falls under GDPR, particularly Article 15. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 2(2)(a), 4(7), 15 EU Charter: Article 47 TFEU: Article 267 Reasoning: The Court emphasized a broad interpretation of "data controller" to include any body determining data processing purposes and means. Activities of the Petitions Committee, whether administrative or political, do not inherently fall outside Union law for GDPR applicability. No specific GDPR exemption exists for parliamentary activities, thus GDPR obligations apply to the Petitions Committee. Impact: Establishes that parliamentary bodies determining data processing purposes and means are bound by GDPR. Ensures the right of access to personal data under GDPR is enforceable even within parliamentary contexts.

Case Overview: Case Name: Patrick Breyer v. Bundesrepublik Deutschland Court: Second Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 19 October 2016 Reference: C-582/14 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of 'personal data' (Directive 95/46/EC, Article 2(a)) Legitimate interests in data processing (Directive 95/46/EC, Article 7(f)) Exemptions related to public security (Directive 95/46/EC, Article 3(2)) Core Facts: Patrick Breyer accessed websites operated by German Federal institutions which stored his dynamic IP address to prevent cyber-attacks. Breyer contested this storage without his specific consent. Judgment: Dynamic IP Address as Personal Data: Dynamic IP addresses, when combined with other data possessed by an Internet Service Provider (ISP), are personal data if the website provider has legal means to obtain the additional data to identify the user. National Law and Legitimate Interests: National law (TMG) must not prevent the balancing of legitimate interests against the protection of user data. Member States' legislation cannot categorically restrict data processing necessary for ensuring general operability of services. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(a), 3(2), 7(f) Recital: 26 Reasoning: Personal Data Definition: Included data that does not directly identify an individual but allows identification by combining separate data. Legitimate Interests: National laws should not impose stricter conditions than those outlined under Article 7(f) of Directive 95/46, which permits data processing essential for legitimate interests unless overridden by the individual's rights. EU Legal Framework: Maintains that balance is required between data protection and the free movement of data. Impact: Clarifies that dynamic IP addresses can be classified as personal data under EU law if they can reasonably facilitate user identification. Establishes that Member States cannot implement overly restrictive laws that prevent the processing of data necessary for maintaining the security and operability of services.

Case Overview: Case Name: TU, RE v. Google LLC Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 8 December 2022 Reference: C-460/20 Key Legal Issues: Right to erasure under GDPR (Article 17(3)(a)) Weighing of conflicting rights under EU Charter (Articles 7, 8, 11, 16) Core Facts: TU and RE requested that Google de-reference links to articles and remove thumbnails of photos portraying them, claiming the articles contained inaccurate and defamatory information. Google refused, citing freedom of expression and information. It's noted that while the articles and photos were removed temporarily, they may be re-posted, thus maintaining the relevance of the request. Judgment: De-referencing without Proving Inaccuracy: De-referencing requests don't require prior legal resolution of the accuracy of content. Data subjects must provide reasonable evidence of inaccuracy but not necessarily a judicial decision. Informative Value of Thumbnails: Thumbnails and their immediate context must be considered separately from the original publication context. If the article remains accessible, removing thumbnails alone is insufficient if they still refer back to the original source. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4, 5, 16, 17(3)(a), 21 Directive 95/46: Articles 6, 12(b), 14(a) EU Charter: Articles 7, 8, 11, 16 Reasoning: The right to data protection must be balanced against other fundamental rights, especially freedom of information. The operator of the search engine is responsible for weighing these rights when processing de-referencing requests. Data subjects cannot be overburdened with proving inaccuracy definitively at the pre-litigation stage. Impact: Clarifies that search engines must evaluate de-referencing requests without awaiting prior court decisions on content accuracy. Ensures data subjects have a practical pathway to request the removal of inaccurate personal data. Establishes a framework for balancing privacy with freedom of expression and information.

Case Overview: Case Name: HYA and Others (Motivation des autorisations des écoutes téléphoniques) Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 16 February 2023 Reference: C-349/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC concerning the confidentiality of electronic communications. Compatibility with Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU (right to an effective remedy and to a fair trial). Core Facts: Criminal proceedings were initiated against HYA and co-defendants for participation in an organized criminal gang. Applications for telephone tapping were submitted, but the judicial authorizations were issued using pre-drafted template texts that lacked individualised reasons. Judgment: Judicial Authorisation Practice: The national practice of issuing judicial decisions with pre-drafted template texts without individualised reasons is not precluded by Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58/EC, provided that the precise reasons for authorization can be easily inferred from cross-reading the decision with the application. The application for authorization must be made accessible to the person against whom the use of special investigative methods was authorized. Fair Trial: Compliance with the requirement to state reasons under Article 47 of the Charter depends on whether the cross-reading allows the affected person and the review court to understand the grounds of the authorization. Applicable Law: Directive 2002/58/EC: Articles 5(1), 15(1) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Article 47 Reasoning: Emphasized the need for balancing the confidentiality of communications (Directive 2002/58/EC) with effective judicial protection (Article 47 of the Charter). Judicial decisions must be comprehensible to the person concerned and the review court via accessible, reasoned applications. Impact: Clarifies the standards for judicial authorizations of surveillance in terms of procedural requirements under EU law. Sets a precedent for the acceptable format and content of judicial decisions authorizing intrusive measures, balancing state security with individual rights.

Case Overview: Case Name: Worten – Equipamentos para o Lar SA v. Autoridade para as Condições de Trabalho (ACT) Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) Date: 30 May 2013 Reference: C-342/12 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of "personal data" (Article 2 Directive 95/46/EC) Security of processing personal data (Article 17(1) Directive 95/46/EC) Lawfulness and necessity of data processing for compliance and public interest (Articles 6 and 7 of Directive 95/46/EC and Article 202 of the Portuguese Employment Code) Core Facts: ACT requested access to Worten’s record of working time for its employees. Worten’s records were computerized, accessible only by the regional manager and not immediately available during the inspection. ACT imposed a fine on Worten for not providing immediate access to these records as required by Portuguese law. Judgment: Personal Data Definition: The records of working time, indicating the start and end times of work and breaks, are considered personal data. Security of Processing: The Member State must ensure technical and organizational measures for data security, but the controller (employer) must implement these measures. Data Accessibility: National legislation requiring immediate access to records for national authorities is justified if necessary for monitoring compliance with working time regulations. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(a), 6(1)(b) and (c), 7(c) and (e), 17(1) Portuguese Employment Code: Article 202 Directive 2003/88/EC: Articles 6(b), 22(1)(c) and (d) Reasoning: Personal Data: Records with working times constitute information related to identifiable individuals (employees). Security Measures: While the Member State must legislate the requirement, the obligation to implement security measures falls on the data controller (employer). Accessibility Necessity: Immediate access by the national authority is necessary for effective monitoring and ensuring legal compliance regarding working conditions. Impact: Confirms working time records as personal data under data protection laws. Establishes the necessity and lawfulness of national laws requiring immediate data access by regulatory authorities for compliance checks. Clarifies the responsibilities of employers in implementing measures to secure personal data in compliance with EU directives.

Case Overview: Case Name: Rīgas satiksme Court: Court of Justice of the European Union, Second Chamber Date: 4 May 2017 Reference: C-13/16 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of "necessity for the realization of the legitimate interests of a third party" under Article 7(f) of Directive 95/46/EC. Obligation of data controllers to disclose personal data for civil claims. Core Facts: Rīgas satiksme, a trolleybus company, sought personal data of an individual involved in causing damage to its vehicle to bring a civil action for damages. The national police provided partial information but withheld the individual's address and identification number. Judgment: Article 7(f) Directive 95/46/EC does not impose an obligation to disclose personal data for civil litigation purposes. Such disclosure is permitted under national law if conditions set forth in Article 7(f) are met: pursuit of a legitimate interest, necessity of data processing, and a balance with the data subject's rights. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC - Articles 2(a), 2(d), 5, 7(f) Latvian Law on the Protection of Personal Data - Article 7 Reasoning: Legitimate Interest: Seeking personal information for legal claims constitutes a legitimate interest. Necessity: Only data strictly necessary for achieving the legitimate purpose (e.g., address or identification number) should be processed. Balance of Interests: Weighs the necessity against the data subject's fundamental rights, including the impact of their age. Impact: Clarifies that EU law allows but does not mandate disclosure of personal data for civil suits. Guides how Member States may align their laws with Directive 95/46/EC regarding data disclosure. Emphasizes balancing legitimate interests with data protection rights on a case-by-case basis.

Case Overview: Case Name: Digital Rights Ireland Ltd. v. Minister for Communications, Marine and Natural Resources and Others; Kärntner Landesregierung v. Seitlinger, Tschohl, and Others Court: Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 8 April 2014 Reference: C-293/12 and C-594/12 Key Legal Issues: Validity of Directive 2006/24/EC under Articles 7, 8, and 11 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. Retention of electronic communications data and its compatibility with privacy and data protection rights. Core Facts: Digital Rights Ireland challenged the legality of national measures and Directive 2006/24 requiring retention of electronic communications data. The Verfassungsgerichtshof (Austrian Constitutional Court) raised issues regarding the compatibility of the Directive with fundamental rights under the EU Charter, affecting privacy and data protection. Judgment: Directive 2006/24/EC Invalid: The Directive involves a wide-ranging and severe interference with the fundamental rights enshrined in Articles 7 and 8 of the Charter, relating to respect for private life and protection of personal data. The Directive fails to provide objective criteria to limit access and use of retained data, and it lacks adequate safeguards against abuse and unlawful access. Retention periods set without differentiation or based on specific criteria also deemed disproportionate. Applicable Law: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 7, 8, 52(1) E-Privacy Directive 2002/58/EC Directive 95/46/EC (Data Protection Directive) Directive 2006/24/EC (Data Retention Directive) Reasoning: The Court highlighted the necessity for clear, precise rules and robust safeguards when handling personal data. A broad obligation to retain data without specific criteria to justify its necessity contravenes fundamental rights. The Directive’s lack of limitations and safeguards concerning data access, storage, and protection was deemed excessive and disproportionate. Impact: The ruling emphasizes stringent requirements for data retention laws to uphold privacy and data protection rights. It limits the scope of acceptable state interference in personal data handling, guiding future legislation on electronic communications and criminal investigations.

Case Overview: Case Name: Willems and Others v. Burgemeesters Court: Fourth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 16 April 2015 Reference: C-446/12, C-448/12, C-449/12 Key Legal Issues: Applicability of Regulation No 2252/2004 to identity cards. Legal guarantees for biometric data usage and storage. Core Facts: Applicants refused to provide biometric data for passports/identity cards, citing privacy and data security concerns. Netherlands law required biometric data storage for issuing documents, potentially in central databases. Judgment: Identity Cards: Regulation No 2252/2004 does not apply to identity cards issued by Member States, regardless of validity period or travel utility. Biometric Data Usage: Regulation No 2252/2004 does not mandate Member States to legally guarantee biometric data will only be used for passport issuance. Broader use and storage of biometric data fall under national legislation, not EU jurisdiction. Applicable Law: Regulation No 2252/2004: Articles 1(3) & 4(3) Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU: Articles 7 & 8 Reasoning: Identity Cards: Explicit exclusion from Regulation No 2252/2004. Biometric Data: Interpretation of Regulation and recitals specify limited EU scope; broader data usage governed by national laws. Impact: Defines scope and limitations of EU regulations regarding biometric data. Affirms Member States' autonomy over broader biometric data usage. Clarifies non-applicability of biometric standards to national identity cards.

Case Overview: Case Name: Orange România SA v. Autoritatea Națională de Supraveghere a Prelucrării Datelor cu Caracter Personal (ANSPDCP) Court: Second Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 11 November 2020 Reference: C-61/19 Key Legal Issues: - Definition and requirements for valid consent under Directive 95/46/EC and GDPR. - Burden of proof for showing valid consent. - Lawfulness and transparency in data processing. Core Facts: - Orange România, a mobile telecom provider, fined by ANSPDCP for collecting and storing copies of customers' identity documents without valid consent. - Contracts contained pre-ticked boxes indicating customers' consent to storage of their ID documents. - Customers required to sign additional forms if they refused consent. Judgment: - Consent must be a freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes. - The court found pre-ticked boxes insufficient to demonstrate valid consent. - Contracts misleading about the possibility of concluding them without consenting to data storage. Applicable Law: - Directive 95/46/EC: Articles 2(h), 6(1)(a), and 7(a) - Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR): Articles 4(11), 5(1)(a), 6(1)(a), 7(1), and 13 Reasoning: - Consent should be an active behavior by the data subject. - Consent documents and clauses need to be clearly distinguishable from other non-related clauses. - Information provided must enable subjects to make informed decisions without misleading them about their options. Impact: - This decision emphasizes stringent requirements for obtaining valid consent under GDPR. - Clarifies burden of proof lies with data controllers to demonstrate consent. - Reinforces comprehensive and clear information must be provided to data subjects, impacting how consent documentation is structured.

Case Overview: Case Name: Fashion ID GmbH & Co. KG v. Verbraucherzentrale NRW eV Court: Second Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 29 July 2019 Reference: C-40/17 Key Legal Issues: Definition of "controller" under Directive 95/46/EC (Article 2(d)). Lawfulness of data processing (Article 7(f)). Requirement of consent (Articles 2(h) and 7(a)). Duty to inform the data subject (Article 10). Standing of consumer-protection associations to bring legal actions (Articles 22-24). Core Facts: Fashion ID embedded Facebook's "Like" button on its website, causing visitors' personal data to be transmitted to Facebook Ireland without their consent or knowledge. Verbraucherzentrale NRW, a consumer protection NGO, filed a complaint claiming this practice violated data protection laws. Fashion ID argued it was not a "controller" as defined in Directive 95/46/EC and questioned the standing of Verbraucherzentrale to bring the action. Judgment: Fashion ID as Controller: Fashion ID is considered a joint controller with Facebook Ireland for the data collection and transmission process despite lacking influence over subsequent data processing performed by Facebook. Lawfulness of Data Processing: Both Fashion ID and Facebook Ireland must pursue and demonstrate legitimate interests for such data processing activities to justify them under Article 7(f). Requirement of Consent and Duty to Inform: The consent and information duties fall on Fashion ID since it initiated the data collection by embedding the "Like" button – applicable solely to operations where it determines the purposes and means. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC, Articles: 2(d), 7(a), 7(f), 10, 22-24 Directive 2002/58/EC (Article 5(3)) Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (GDPR, Article 80(2)) Reasoning: Joint Controllership: Emphasizes collaborative roles in determining data processing means and purposes and ensures effective data subject protection. Legal Standing: Affirms that national laws permitting NGO legal actions align with objectives of comprehensive data protection. Impact: Clarifies joint controller responsibilities under data protection law. Establishes the standing of consumer protection bodies to litigate for data protection infringements. Influences the practice of embedding third-party plugins regarding consent and information duties.

Concise Summary: Case Overview: Case Name: IAB Europe v. Gegevensbeschermingsautoriteit Court: Fourth Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 7 March 2024 Reference: C-604/22 Key Legal Issues: Classification of "personal data" as per GDPR (Article 4(1)) Determination of "data controller" (Article 4(7)) Concept and scope of "joint controllers" (Article 26(1)) Core Facts: IAB Europe developed the Transparency & Consent Framework (TCF) to ensure GDPR compliance in Real Time Bidding (RTB) for online advertising. The TCF generates a Transparency and Consent String (TC String) containing user consent preferences. The Belgian Data Protection Authority (DPA) classifies the TC String as personal data and designates IAB Europe as a data controller, demanding compliance and imposing fines. Judgment: Classification of TC String as Personal Data: TC String is considered personal data if it can be associated with an identifier (e.g., IP address), even if IAB Europe cannot directly access or combine it with identifiers. IAB Europe as Joint Controller: IAB Europe is a joint controller since it influences the processing through the TCF, even though it doesn't have direct access to the personal data. Scope of Joint Controllership: The responsibility does not automatically extend to subsequent processing by third parties unless IAB Europe influences the purposes and means of such processing. Applicable Law: GDPR Articles: 4(1), 4(7), 6(1)(f), 24(1), 26(1) EU Charter: Articles 7 and 8 GDPR Recitals: 1, 10, 26, 30 Reasoning: Broad definition of personal data and controller to ensure high-level data protection. Control implies influence over data processing purposes and means, even indirectly. Limits the scope of joint controllership to specific processing activities influenced by the controller. Impact: Clarifies the classification scope of personal data, especially in digital advertising. Elaborates responsibilities and limitations of joint controllership in data processing frameworks. Affects compliance strategies for organizations setting data processing standards.

Case Overview: Case Name: Spetsializirana prokuratura Court: Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 1 January 1970 Reference: C-350/21 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Articles 8(1) and (2)(a) of Directive 2016/343 concerning presumption of innocence. National implementing measures and their compatibility with EU law. Procedural rights in criminal investigations. Core Facts: The Bulgarian Specialized Prosecutor's Office authorized media to broadcast footage of a suspect in handcuffs during a high-profile investigation. This broadcast occurred before the suspect had been proven guilty in a court of law, raising concerns regarding the presumption of innocence. Bulgaria's legal framework allowed such disclosures under certain conditions. Judgment: Violation of Presumption of Innocence: The Court determined that broadcasting footage of a suspect in restraints before a trial infringes on the presumption of innocence. Any pre-judicial representations must be limited to what is strictly necessary to inform the public without jeopardizing the accused's rights. Compatibility with EU Law: Bulgaria's legal provisions allowing such media disclosures were found incompatible with the directive on the presumption of innocence. Necessary reforms must be implemented to align national laws with EU standards. Applicable Law: Directive 2016/343: Articles 8(1), 8(2)(a) EU Charter of Fundamental Rights: Articles 47, 48(1) Reasoning: Balancing Public Interest and Individual Rights: The Court emphasized the need to balance informing the public with safeguarding the fundamental rights of suspects. Interpretation of Directive: Clarified the directive’s application to ensure suspects are not portrayed in a manner suggesting guilt before judicial determination. Impact: Establishes strict limitations on pre-trial media representations of suspects to uphold the presumption of innocence. Calls for national legal reforms to better align with EU directives concerning procedural rights in criminal contexts.

Concise Summary: Case Overview: Case Name: Smaranda Bara and Others v. Președintele Casei Naționale de Asigurări de Sănătate, Casa Naţională de Asigurări de Sănătate, Agenția Națională de Administrare Fiscală (ANAF) Court: Third Chamber of the Court of Justice of the European Union Date: 1 October 2015 Reference: C-201/14 Key Legal Issues: Obligation to inform data subjects when collecting personal data (Articles 10 and 11, Directive 95/46/EC) Exceptions to the obligation to inform (Article 13, Directive 95/46/EC) Core Facts: ANAF transferred tax data related to income of self-employed persons to CNAS without informing the data subjects. CNAS used the transferred data to impose health insurance contributions. Judgment: Articles 10, 11, and 13 of Directive 95/46/EC preclude national measures allowing the transfer and subsequent processing of personal data by public administrative bodies without informing data subjects of such actions. Applicable Law: Directive 95/46/EC Articles: 2(a)(b), 6(1), 7, 10, 11, 13 Law No 95/2006 (Romania): Articles 215, 315 Reasoning: Fair Processing: Data subjects must be informed to exercise their rights. Legislative Basis: Transfer of data must be based on official legislation providing necessary safeguards, which was not the case here with the 2007 Protocol. Impact: This ruling reinforces the imperative of informing data subjects about data processing, thereby ensuring transparency and compliance with data protection laws. Imposes stricter requirements on administrative bodies regarding the transfer and processing of personal data, ensuring such actions are underpinned by legislative measures.

Case Overview: Case Name: Tele2 (Netherlands) BV, Ziggo BV, Vodafone Libertel BV v. Autoriteit Consument en Markt (ACM) Court: Court of Justice of the European Union (Second Chamber) Date: 15 March 2017 Reference: C-536/15 Key Legal Issues: Interpretation of Article 25(2) of Directive 2002/22/EC (Universal Service Directive) regarding cross-border data requests. Compliance with Article 12 of Directive 2002/58/EC (Directive on privacy and electronic communications). Core Facts: Tele2, Ziggo, and Vodafone Libertel, based in the Netherlands, refused to provide subscriber data to the Belgium-based European Directory Assistance NV (EDA) for directory enquiry services. ACM's decision mandated Dutch companies to provide this data fairly, objectively, and non-discriminatory. Judgment: Cross-Border Requests: Article 25(2) of the Universal Service Directive includes requests from entities in other Member States for subscriber data for directory services. Subscriber Consent: Providers cannot differentiate in subscriber consent requests based on the Member State of the data requestor, ensuring consistent treatment and compliance with non-discrimination principles. Applicable Law: Universal Service Directive (Directive 2002/22/EC), specifically Article 25(2). Directive on privacy and electronic communications (Directive 2002/58/EC), specifically Article 12. Reasoning: Emphasis on the Universal Service Directive’s objective of ensuring good-quality services via effective competition across the EU. Ensuring non-discriminatory access to subscriber information promotes market competition and consumer choice. Impact: Reinforces the obligation to meet cross-border data requests in a non-discriminatory manner. Harmonizes the approach to subscriber consent across Member States, enhancing data protection consistency within the EU.
